00:05:40.166 --> 00:05:42.522
will, 99 percent of the time,
be way off the mark.

00:05:43.300 --> 00:05:45.934
This is because magic
is all about directing attention.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.875
If, for instance, I didn't want
you to look at my right hand,

00:05:48.899 --> 00:05:50.134
then I don't look at it.

00:05:50.158 --> 00:05:52.929
But if I wanted you
to look at my right hand,

00:05:52.953 --> 00:05:54.175
then I look at it, too.

00:05:54.199 --> 00:05:56.318
You see, it's very simple,
once you know how,

00:05:56.342 --> 00:05:58.045
but very complicated in other ways.

00:05:58.069 --> 00:06:00.586
I'm going to give you
some demonstrations right now.

00:06:00.610 --> 00:06:03.468
I need two people to help me out
real quick. Can you come up?

00:06:03.492 --> 00:06:07.528
And let's see, down at the end, here,
can you also come up, real quick?

00:06:07.552 --> 00:06:08.934
Do you mind? Yes, at the end.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.339
OK, give them a round of applause
as they come up.

00:06:11.363 --> 00:06:13.339
You might want to use the stairs, there.

00:06:13.363 --> 00:06:15.935
(Applause)

00:06:15.959 --> 00:06:18.260
It's very important
for everybody here to realize

00:06:18.284 --> 00:06:20.034
I haven't set anything up with you.

00:06:20.058 --> 00:06:21.932
You don't know what will happen, right?

00:06:21.956 --> 00:06:24.433
Would you mind just standing
over here for a moment?

00:06:24.457 --> 00:06:25.851
Your name is?
Nicole: Nicole.

00:06:25.875 --> 00:06:26.882
KB: Nicole, and?

00:06:26.906 --> 00:06:27.915
(Telephone ringing)

00:06:27.939 --> 00:06:31.871
KB: Actually, here's the thing,
answer it, answer it, answer it.

00:06:31.895 --> 00:06:32.934
(Laughter)

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.934
Is it a girl?
Man: They've already gone.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.308
KB: OK, swap over positions.

00:06:36.332 --> 00:06:38.934
Can you stand over here?
This will make it easier.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.534
Pity, I would have told them
it was the ace of spades.

00:06:41.558 --> 00:06:42.703
OK, a little bit closer.

00:06:42.727 --> 00:06:43.879
(Laughter)

00:06:43.903 --> 00:06:47.473
OK, a little bit closer, come over --
they look really nervous up here.

00:06:47.497 --> 00:06:48.934
Do you believe in witchcraft?

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.034
Nicole: No.

00:06:50.058 --> 00:06:51.337
KB: Voodoo?
Nicole: No.

00:06:51.361 --> 00:06:53.726
KB: Things that go bump in the night?
Nicole: No.

00:06:53.750 --> 00:06:55.334
KB: Besides, who's next, no, OK.

00:06:55.358 --> 00:06:57.750
I want you to just stand
exactly like this for me,

00:06:57.774 --> 00:06:59.744
pull up your sleeves, if you don't mind.

00:06:59.768 --> 00:07:01.285
OK, now, I want you to be aware

00:07:01.309 --> 00:07:03.334
of all the different
sensations around you,

00:07:03.358 --> 00:07:05.234
because we'll try a voodoo experiment.

00:07:05.258 --> 00:07:09.234
I want you to be aware of the sensations,
but don't say anything until I ask you,

00:07:09.258 --> 00:07:11.534
and don't open your eyes until I ask you.

00:07:11.558 --> 00:07:13.521
From this point onwards, close your eyes,

00:07:13.545 --> 00:07:15.366
do not say anything, do not open them,

00:07:15.390 --> 00:07:16.958
be aware of the sensations.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.934
Yes or no, did you feel anything?

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:27.959
Nicole: Yes.

00:07:27.983 --> 00:07:29.996
KB: You did feel that? What did you feel?

00:07:30.020 --> 00:07:31.672
Nicole: A touch on my back.

00:07:31.696 --> 00:07:33.410
KB: How many times did you feel it?

00:07:35.210 --> 00:07:36.258
Nicole: Twice.

00:07:36.282 --> 00:07:38.948
KB: Twice. OK, extend your left arm
out in front of you.

00:07:38.972 --> 00:07:40.403
Extend your left arm, OK.

00:07:41.508 --> 00:07:42.934
OK, keep it there.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.397
Be aware of the sensations, don't say
anything, don't open your eyes, OK.

00:07:54.934 --> 00:07:56.315
Did you feel anything, there?

00:07:56.339 --> 00:07:57.965
Nicole: Yes.
KB: What did you feel?

00:07:57.989 --> 00:07:59.021
Nicole: Three --

00:07:59.045 --> 00:08:01.068
KB: Like a tickling sensation?
Nicole: Yes.

00:08:01.092 --> 00:08:02.934
KB: Can you show us where?

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.934
OK, excellent. Open your eyes.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:05.981
I never touched you.

00:08:06.005 --> 00:08:09.539
I just touched his back,
and I just touched his arm.

00:08:09.563 --> 00:08:10.934
A voodoo experiment.

00:08:12.092 --> 00:08:14.934
(Laughter)

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.387
Yeah, I walk around nightclubs
all night like this.

00:08:17.411 --> 00:08:19.873
(Laughter)

00:08:19.897 --> 00:08:21.951
You just take a seat
over here for a second.

00:08:21.975 --> 00:08:23.934
I'm going to use you again, in a moment.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.530
Can you take a seat
right over here, if you don't mind.

00:08:26.554 --> 00:08:27.705
Sit right here.
Man: OK.

00:08:28.427 --> 00:08:30.934
KB: OK, take a seat. Excellent, OK.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.934
Now, what I want you to do
is look directly at me, OK,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.101
just take a deep breath
in through your nose,

00:08:36.125 --> 00:08:38.675
letting it out through
your mouth, and relax.

00:08:38.699 --> 00:08:42.417
Allow your eyes to close,
on five, four, three, two, one.

00:08:42.441 --> 00:08:43.934
Close your eyes right now.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.934
OK, now, I'm not hypnotizing you,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.911
I'm merely placing you in a heightened
state of synchronicity,

00:08:48.935 --> 00:08:50.934
so our minds are along the same lines.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.934
And as you sink and drift and float
into this relaxed state of mind,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.934
I'm going to take your left hand,
and just place it up here.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.129
I want you to hold it there
just for a moment,

00:09:00.153 --> 00:09:02.004
and I only want you to allow your hand

00:09:02.028 --> 00:09:04.407
to sink and drift and float
back to the tabletop

00:09:04.431 --> 00:09:05.934
at the same rate and speed

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:09.153
as you drift and float into this
relaxed state of awareness,

00:09:09.177 --> 00:09:12.216
and allow it to go all the way
down to the tabletop.

00:09:12.240 --> 00:09:15.359
That's it, all the way down,
all the way down.

00:09:15.383 --> 00:09:17.986
and further, and further.

00:09:18.010 --> 00:09:19.279
Excellent.

00:09:19.303 --> 00:09:22.208
I want you to allow your hand
to stick firmly to the tabletop.

00:09:22.232 --> 00:09:24.022
OK, now, allow it to stay there.

00:09:24.563 --> 00:09:27.540
OK, now, in a moment,
you'll feel a certain pressure, OK,

00:09:27.564 --> 00:09:29.609
and I want you
to be aware of the pressure.

00:09:34.234 --> 00:09:35.933
Just be aware of the pressure.

00:09:37.538 --> 00:09:39.395
And I only want you to allow your hand

00:09:39.419 --> 00:09:42.943
to float slowly back up from the tabletop
as you feel the pressure release,

00:09:42.967 --> 00:09:45.057
but only when you feel
the pressure release.

00:09:45.797 --> 00:09:47.934
Do you understand? Just answer yes or no.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:48.979
Man: Yes.

00:09:55.098 --> 00:09:56.320
KB: Hold it right there.

00:09:56.344 --> 00:09:58.439
And only when you feel
the pressure go back,

00:09:58.463 --> 00:10:00.699
allow your hand to drift
back to the tabletop,

00:10:00.723 --> 00:10:02.438
but only when you feel the pressure.

00:10:06.509 --> 00:10:08.589
(Laughter)

00:10:08.613 --> 00:10:10.994
OK, that was wonderfully done.
Let's try it again.

00:10:21.611 --> 00:10:25.517
Excellent. Now that you've got the idea,
let's try something even more interesting.

00:10:25.541 --> 00:10:28.541
Allow it to stick firmly
to the tabletop, keep your eyes closed.

00:10:28.565 --> 00:10:31.581
Can you stand up?
Just stand, stage forward.

00:10:31.605 --> 00:10:34.064
I want you to point directly
at his forehead.

00:10:34.088 --> 00:10:35.286
OK.

00:10:35.310 --> 00:10:37.563
Imagine a connection between you and him.

00:10:38.365 --> 00:10:40.582
Only when you want
the pressure to be released,

00:10:40.606 --> 00:10:42.248
make an upward gesture, like this,

00:10:42.272 --> 00:10:44.265
but only when you want it to be released.

00:10:44.289 --> 00:10:45.938
You can wait as long as you want,

00:10:45.962 --> 00:10:48.058
but only when you want
the pressure released.

00:10:55.115 --> 00:10:56.638
OK, let's try it again.

00:10:56.662 --> 00:10:58.934
OK, now, imagine the connection, OK.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.934
Point directly at his forehead.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.816
Only when you want the pressure
released, we'll try it again.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.934
OK, it worked that time, excellent.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.934
And hold it there, both of you.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:14.197
Only when you want the pressure
to go back, make a downward gesture.

00:11:14.221 --> 00:11:15.793
You can wait as long as you want.

00:11:18.275 --> 00:11:21.767
You did it pretty quickly,
but it went down, OK.

00:11:21.791 --> 00:11:23.934
Now, I want you to be aware
that in a moment,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.366
when I snap my fingers,
your eyes will open, again.

00:11:26.390 --> 00:11:29.585
It's OK to remember to forget,
or forget to remember what happened.

00:11:29.609 --> 00:11:32.379
Most people ask you, "What
the hell just happened up here?"

00:11:32.403 --> 00:11:34.786
But it's OK that even though
you're not hypnotized,

00:11:34.810 --> 00:11:37.042
you will forget everything that happened.

00:11:37.066 --> 00:11:39.934
On five, four, three, two, one --
open your eyes, wide awake.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.262
Give them a round of applause,
as they go back to their seats.

00:11:43.286 --> 00:11:44.799
(Applause)

00:11:44.823 --> 00:11:46.190
OK, you can go back.

00:11:46.214 --> 00:11:49.483
(Applause)

00:11:50.173 --> 00:11:52.458
I once saw a film called
"The Gods Are Crazy."

00:11:52.482 --> 00:11:54.934
Has anybody here seen that film? Yeah.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.566
Remember when they threw
the Coke out of the airplane,

00:11:57.590 --> 00:11:59.918
and it landed on the ground,
and it didn't break?

00:11:59.942 --> 00:12:02.266
Now, see, that's because
Coke bottles are solid.

00:12:02.804 --> 00:12:06.091
It's nearly impossible
to break a Coke bottle.

00:12:06.115 --> 00:12:07.512
Do you want to try it?

00:12:09.227 --> 00:12:11.633
Good job. She's not taking any chances.

00:12:11.657 --> 00:12:12.934
(Laughter)

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.339
You see, psychokinesis
is the paranormal influence

00:12:15.363 --> 00:12:17.846
of the mind on physical
events and processes.

00:12:18.340 --> 00:12:19.934
For some magicians or mentalists,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.934
sometimes the spoon will bend
or melt, sometimes it will not.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.442
Sometimes the object will slide
across the table, sometimes it will not.

00:12:27.466 --> 00:12:29.738
It depends on how much
energy you have that day,

00:12:29.762 --> 00:12:30.826
so on and so forth.

00:12:30.850 --> 00:12:33.708
We're going to try an experiment
in psychokinesis, right now.

00:12:33.732 --> 00:12:35.861
Come right over here, next to me.
Excellent.

00:12:35.885 --> 00:12:37.670
Now, have a look at the Coke bottle.

00:12:37.694 --> 00:12:41.266
Make sure it is solid, there's only
one hole, and it's a normal Coke bottle.

00:12:41.290 --> 00:12:44.291
And you can whack it against the table,
if you want; be careful.

00:12:44.315 --> 00:12:46.315
Even though it's solid, I'm standing away.

00:12:46.339 --> 00:12:49.689
I want you to pinch right here
with two fingers and your thumb.

00:12:49.713 --> 00:12:52.267
Excellent.
Now, I've got a shard of glass here, OK.

00:12:52.291 --> 00:12:54.244
I want you to examine the shard of glass.

00:12:54.268 --> 00:12:56.843
Careful, it's sharp.
Just hold on to it for a moment.

00:12:56.867 --> 00:12:58.034
Now, hold it out here.

00:12:58.059 --> 00:13:01.959
I want you to imagine, right now,
a broken relationship from many years ago.

00:13:02.505 --> 00:13:05.586
I want you to imagine
all the negative energy

00:13:05.610 --> 00:13:07.762
from that broken
relationship, from that guy,

00:13:07.786 --> 00:13:10.290
being imparted into the broken
piece of glass,

00:13:10.314 --> 00:13:11.934
which will represent him, OK.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.006
But I want you to take this
very seriously.

00:13:14.030 --> 00:13:16.316
Stare at the glass,
ignore everybody right here.

00:13:16.340 --> 00:13:19.463
In a moment, you'll feel
a certain sensation, OK,

00:13:19.487 --> 00:13:21.303
and when you feel that sensation,

00:13:21.327 --> 00:13:23.934
I want you to drop the piece
of glass into the bottle.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:28.855
Think of that guy, that ba -- that guy.

00:13:28.879 --> 00:13:29.934
(Laughter)

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.371
I'm trying to be good here.

00:13:31.395 --> 00:13:33.205
OK, and when you feel the sensation --

00:13:33.229 --> 00:13:35.488
it might take a while --
drop it into the glass.

00:13:47.767 --> 00:13:48.767
OK, drop it in.

00:13:49.299 --> 00:13:51.934
Now, imagine all that negative
energy in there.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.591
Imagine his name
and imagine him inside the glass.

00:13:54.615 --> 00:13:56.859
And I want you to release
that negative energy

00:13:56.883 --> 00:13:58.407
by shaking it from side to side.

00:13:59.524 --> 00:14:00.525
(Burst)

00:14:00.549 --> 00:14:02.934
(Laughter)

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.490
That was a lot of negative energy,
built up in there.

00:14:05.514 --> 00:14:07.576
(Laughter)

00:14:07.600 --> 00:14:10.934
(Applause)

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.959
I also want you to look at me
and think of his name.

00:14:13.983 --> 00:14:17.958
OK, think of how many letters
in the title of his name.

00:14:17.982 --> 00:14:19.664
There's five letters in the title.

00:14:19.688 --> 00:14:21.935
You didn't react to that,
so it's four letters.

00:14:21.959 --> 00:14:23.934
Think of one of the letters in the title.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.934
There's a K in his name, there is a K.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.334
I knew that because my name
starts with a K also,

00:14:28.358 --> 00:14:31.195
but his name doesn't start
with a K, it starts with an M.

00:14:31.219 --> 00:14:33.641
Tell Mike I said hello,
the next time you see him.

00:14:33.665 --> 00:14:35.334
Was that his name?
Nicole: Mm-hmm.

00:14:35.358 --> 00:14:37.135
KB: OK, give her a round of applause.

00:14:37.159 --> 00:14:42.767
(Applause)

00:14:42.791 --> 00:14:43.934
Thank you.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.916
(Applause)

00:14:49.127 --> 00:14:50.426
(Applause ends)

00:14:50.450 --> 00:14:52.934
I've got one more thing
to share with you right now.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.339
Actually, Chris, I was going
to pick you for this,

00:14:55.363 --> 00:14:57.602
but instead of picking you,
can you hop up here

00:14:57.626 --> 00:14:59.934
and pick a victim
for this next experiment?

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.530
And it should be a male victim,
that's the only thing.

00:15:02.554 --> 00:15:03.934
Chris Anderson: Oh, OK.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.344
KB: I was going to use you,

00:15:05.368 --> 00:15:07.934
but I decided I might want
to come back another year.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:08.973
(Laughter)

00:15:08.997 --> 00:15:11.109
CA: Well, to reward him
for saying "eureka,"

00:15:11.133 --> 00:15:14.701
and for selecting Michael Mercil to come
and talk to us -- Steve Jurvetson.

00:15:14.725 --> 00:15:16.471
KB: OK, Steve, come on up here.

00:15:16.495 --> 00:15:17.567
(Applause)

00:15:17.591 --> 00:15:18.632
CA: You knew!

00:15:18.656 --> 00:15:22.958
KB: OK, Steve, I want you to take
a seat, right behind here. Excellent.

00:15:24.647 --> 00:15:26.934
Now, Steve -- oh, you
can check underneath.

00:15:28.758 --> 00:15:31.321
Go ahead, I've no fancy
assistants underneath there.

00:15:31.345 --> 00:15:33.860
They insist that because I was a magician,

00:15:33.884 --> 00:15:35.424
put a nice, black tablecloth on.

00:15:35.448 --> 00:15:36.861
There you are, OK.

00:15:36.885 --> 00:15:37.934
(Laughter)

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.934
I've got four wooden plinths here, Steve.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.934
One, two, three and four.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.197
Now, they're all the exact
same except this one

00:15:45.221 --> 00:15:47.936
obviously has a stainless steel
spike sticking out of it.

00:15:47.960 --> 00:15:50.425
I want you to examine it,
and make sure it's solid.

00:15:53.053 --> 00:15:54.060
Happy?

00:15:54.084 --> 00:15:56.038
Steve Jurvetson: Mmm, yes.

00:15:56.062 --> 00:15:59.569
KB: OK. Now, Steve, I'm going
to stand in front of the table,

00:15:59.593 --> 00:16:01.365
When I stand in front of the table,

00:16:01.389 --> 00:16:03.504
I want you to put the cups on the plinths,

00:16:03.528 --> 00:16:05.767
in any order you want,
and then mix them all up,

00:16:05.791 --> 00:16:08.562
so nobody has any idea where
the spike is, all right?

00:16:08.586 --> 00:16:09.934
SJ: No one in the audience?

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.934
KB: Yes, and just to help you out,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.944
I'll block them from view,
so nobody can see what you're doing.

00:16:14.968 --> 00:16:17.540
I'll also look away. So, go
ahead and mix them up, now.

00:16:17.564 --> 00:16:19.240
OK, and tell me when you're done.

00:16:21.891 --> 00:16:23.874
(Laughter)

00:16:24.668 --> 00:16:27.128
(Laughter)

00:16:28.530 --> 00:16:30.530
KB: You done?
SJ: Almost.

00:16:30.554 --> 00:16:33.491
KB: Almost, oh. OK, you're making
sure that's well hidden.

00:16:34.491 --> 00:16:38.934
Oh, we've got one here,
we've got one here.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.934
(Applause)

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
So, all right, we'll leave them like that.

00:16:43.982 --> 00:16:45.934
(Laughter)

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.959
I'm going to have the last laugh, though.

00:16:47.983 --> 00:16:49.934
(Laughter)

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:54.934
Now, Steve, you know where the spike is,
but nobody else, does? Correct?

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:58.197
But I don't want you to know either,
so swivel around on your chair.

00:16:59.173 --> 00:17:02.221
They'll keep an eye on me
to make sure I don't do anything funny.

00:17:02.245 --> 00:17:04.292
No, stay around, OK.

00:17:10.834 --> 00:17:12.516
Now, Steve, look back.

00:17:12.540 --> 00:17:16.310
Now you don't know where the spike is,
and I don't know where it is either.

00:17:16.334 --> 00:17:18.801
Now, is there any way to see
through this blindfold?

00:17:19.480 --> 00:17:20.512
SJ: Put this on?

00:17:20.536 --> 00:17:23.283
KB: No, just, is there any way
to see through it? No?

title: The new era of positive psychology
transcript: When I was President of the American Psychological Association, they tried to media-train me. And an encounter I had with CNN summarizes what I'm going to be talking about today, which is the eleventh reason to be optimistic. The editor of Discover told us 10 of them; I'm going to give you the eleventh.So they came to me, CNN, and they said, "Professor Seligman — would you tell us about the state of psychology today? We'd like to interview you about that." And I said, "Great." And she said, "But this is CNN, so you only get a sound bite." I said, "Well, how many words do I get?" And she said, "Well, one."(Laughter)And the cameras rolled, and she said, "Professor Seligman, what is the state of psychology today?" "Good."(Laughter)"Cut! Cut. That won't do. We'd really better give you a longer sound bite." "How many words do I get this time?" "Well, you get two."(Laughter)"Doctor Seligman, what is the state of psychology today?" "Not good."(Laughter)"Look, Doctor Seligman, we can see you're really not comfortable in this medium. We'd better give you a real sound bite. This time you can have three words. Professor Seligman, what is the state of psychology today?" "Not good enough." That's what I'm going to be talking about.I want to say why psychology was good, why it was not good, and how it may become, in the next 10 years, good enough. And by parallel summary, I want to say the same thing about technology, about entertainment and design, because I think the issues are very similar.So, why was psychology good? Well, for more than 60 years, psychology worked within the disease model. Ten years ago, when I was on an airplane and I introduced myself to my seatmate, and told them what I did, they'd move away from me, because, quite rightly, they were saying psychology is about finding what's wrong with you. Spot the loony. And now, when I tell people what I do, they move toward me.What was good about psychology — about the $30 billion investment NIMH made, about working in the disease model, about what you mean by psychology — is that, 60 years ago, none of the disorders were treatable; it was entirely smoke and mirrors. And now, 14 of the disorders are treatable, two of them actually curable.And the other thing that happened is that a science developed, a science of mental illness. We found out we could take fuzzy concepts like depression, alcoholism, and measure them with rigor; that we could create a classification of the mental illnesses; that we could understand the causality of the mental illnesses. We could look across time at the same people — people, for example, who were genetically vulnerable to schizophrenia — and ask what the contribution of mothering, of genetics are, and we could isolate third variables by doing experiments on the mental illnesses.And best of all, we were able, in the last 50 years, to invent drug treatments and psychological treatments. And then we were able to test them rigorously, in random-assignment, placebo-controlled designs, throw out the things that didn't work, keep the things that actively did.The conclusion of that is, psychology and psychiatry of the last 60 years can actually claim that we can make miserable people less miserable. And I think that's terrific. I'm proud of it. But what was not good, the consequences of that, were three things.The first was moral; that psychologists and psychiatrists became victimologists, pathologizers; that our view of human nature was that if you were in trouble, bricks fell on you. And we forgot that people made choices and decisions. We forgot responsibility. That was the first cost.The second cost was that we forgot about you people. We forgot about improving normal lives. We forgot about a mission to make relatively untroubled people happier, more fulfilled, more productive. And "genius," "high-talent," became a dirty word. No one works on that.And the third problem about the disease model is, in our rush to do something about people in trouble, in our rush to do something about repairing damage, it never occurred to us to develop interventions to make people happier — positive interventions.So that was not good. And so that's what led people like Nancy Etcoff, Dan Gilbert, Mike Csikszentmihalyi and myself to work in something I call, "positive psychology," which has three aims. The first is that psychology should be just as concerned with human strength as it is with weakness. It should be just as concerned with building strength as with repairing damage. It should be interested in the best things in life. And it should be just as concerned with making the lives of normal people fulfilling, and with genius, with nurturing high talent.So in the last 10 years and the hope for the future, we've seen the beginnings of a science of positive psychology, a science of what makes life worth living. It turns out that we can measure different forms of happiness. And any of you, for free, can go to that website —[www.authentichappiness.org]and take the entire panoply of tests of happiness. You can ask, how do you stack up for positive emotion, for meaning, for flow, against literally tens of thousands of other people? We created the opposite of the diagnostic manual of the insanities: a classification of the strengths and virtues that looks at the sex ratio, how they're defined, how to diagnose them, what builds them and what gets in their way. We found that we could discover the causation of the positive states, the relationship between left hemispheric activity and right hemispheric activity, as a cause of happiness.I've spent my life working on extremely miserable people, and I've asked the question: How do extremely miserable people differ from the rest of you? And starting about six years ago, we asked about extremely happy people. How do they differ from the rest of us? It turns out there's one way, very surprising — they're not more religious, they're not in better shape, they don't have more money, they're not better looking, they don't have more good events and fewer bad events. The one way in which they differ: they're extremely social. They don't sit in seminars on Saturday morning.(Laughter)They don't spend time alone. Each of them is in a romantic relationship and each has a rich repertoire of friends.But watch out here — this is merely correlational data, not causal, and it's about happiness in the first, "Hollywood" sense, I'm going to talk about, happiness of ebullience and giggling and good cheer. And I'm going to suggest to you that's not nearly enough, in just a moment. We found we could begin to look at interventions over the centuries, from the Buddha to Tony Robbins. About 120 interventions have been proposed that allegedly make people happy. And we find that we've been able to manualize many of them, and we actually carry out random-assignment efficacy and effectiveness studies. That is, which ones actually make people lastingly happier? In a couple of minutes, I'll tell you about some of those results.But the upshot of this is that the mission I want psychology to have, in addition to its mission of curing the mentally ill, and in addition to its mission of making miserable people less miserable, is, can psychology actually make people happier? And to ask that question — "happy" is not a word I use very much — we've had to break it down into what I think is askable about "happy." And I believe there are three different — I call them "different" because different interventions build them, it's possible to have one rather than the other — three different happy lives. The first happy life is the pleasant life. This is a life in which you have as much positive emotion as you possibly can, and the skills to amplify it. The second is a life of engagement: a life in your work, your parenting, your love, your leisure; time stops for you. That's what Aristotle was talking about. And third, the meaningful life. I want to say a little bit about each of those lives and what we know about them.The first life is the pleasant life, and it's simply, as best we can find it, it's having as many of the pleasures as you can, as much positive emotion as you can, and learning the skills — savoring, mindfulness — that amplify them, that stretch them over time and space. But the pleasant life has three drawbacks, and it's why positive psychology is not happy-ology, and why it doesn't end here.The first drawback is, it turns out the pleasant life, your experience of positive emotion, is about 50 percent heritable, and, in fact, not very modifiable. So the different tricks that Matthieu and I and others know about increasing the amount of positive emotion in your life are 15 to 20 percent tricks, getting more of it. Second is that positive emotion habituates. It habituates rapidly, indeed. It's all like French vanilla ice cream: the first taste is 100 percent; by the time you're down to the sixth taste, it's gone. And, as I said, it's not particularly malleable.And this leads to the second life. I have to tell you about my friend Len, to talk about why positive psychology is more than positive emotion, more than building pleasure. In two of the three great arenas of life, by the time Len was 30, Len was enormously successful. The first arena was work. By the time he was 20, he was an options trader. By the time he was 25, he was a multimillionaire and the head of an options trading company. Second, in play, he's a national champion bridge player. But in the third great arena of life, love, Len is an abysmal failure. And the reason he was, was that Len is a cold fish.(Laughter)Len is an introvert. American women said to Len, when he dated them, "You're no fun. You don't have positive emotion. Get lost." And Len was wealthy enough to be able to afford a Park Avenue psychoanalyst, who for five years tried to find the sexual trauma that had somehow locked positive emotion inside of him. But it turned out there wasn't any sexual trauma. It turned out that — Len grew up in Long Island and he played football and watched football, and played bridge. Len is in the bottom five percent of what we call positive affectivities.The question is: Is Len unhappy? And I want to say, not. Contrary to what psychology told us about the bottom 50 percent of the human race in positive affectivity, I think Len is one of the happiest people I know. He's not consigned to the hell of unhappiness, and that's because Len, like most of you, is enormously capable of flow. When he walks onto the floor of the American Exchange at 9:30 in the morning, time stops for him. And it stops till the closing bell. When the first card is played till 10 days later, when the tournament is over, time stops for Len.And this is indeed what Mike Csikszentmihalyi has been talking about, about flow. And it's distinct from pleasure in a very important way: pleasure has raw feel — you know it's happening; it's thought and feeling. But what Mike told you yesterday — during flow ... you can't feel anything. You're one with the music. Time stops. You have intense concentration. And this is indeed the characteristic of what we think of as the good life. And we think there's a recipe for it, and it's knowing what your highest strengths are — again, there's a valid test of what your five highest strengths are — and then re-crafting your life to use them as much as you possibly can. Re-crafting your work, your love, your play, your friendship, your parenting.Just one example. One person I worked with was a bagger at Genuardi's. Hated the job. She's working her way through college. Her highest strength was social intelligence. So she re-crafted bagging to make the encounter with her the social highlight of every customer's day. Now, obviously she failed. But what she did was to take her highest strengths, and re-craft work to use them as much as possible. What you get out of that is not smiley-ness. You don't look like Debbie Reynolds. You don't giggle a lot. What you get is more absorption.So, that's the second path. The first path, positive emotion; the second path is eudaemonian flow; and the third path is meaning. This is the most venerable of the happinesses, traditionally. And meaning, in this view, consists of — very parallel to eudaemonia — it consists of knowing what your highest strengths are, and using them to belong to and in the service of something larger than you are.I mentioned that for all three kinds of lives — the pleasant life, the good life, the meaningful life — people are now hard at work on the question: Are there things that lastingly change those lives? And the answer seems to be yes. And I'll just give you some samples of it. It's being done in a rigorous manner. It's being done in the same way that we test drugs to see what really works. So we do random-assignment, placebo-controlled, long-term studies of different interventions. Just to sample the kind of interventions that we find have an effect: when we teach people about the pleasant life, how to have more pleasure in your life, one of your assignments is to take the mindfulness skills, the savoring skills, and you're assigned to design a beautiful day. Next Saturday, set a day aside, design yourself a beautiful day, and use savoring and mindfulness to enhance those pleasures. And we can show in that way that the pleasant life is enhanced.Gratitude visit. I want you all to do this with me now, if you would. Close your eyes. I'd like you to remember someone who did something enormously important that changed your life in a good direction, and who you never properly thanked. The person has to be alive. Now, OK, you can open your eyes. I hope all of you have such a person. Your assignment, when you're learning the gratitude visit, is to write a 300-word testimonial to that person, call them on the phone in Phoenix, ask if you can visit, don't tell them why. Show up at their door, you read the testimonial — everyone weeps when this happens. And what happens is, when we test people one week later, a month later, three months later, they're both happier and less depressed.Another example is a strengths date, in which we get couples to identify their highest strengths on the strengths test, and then to design an evening in which they both use their strengths. We find this is a strengthener of relationships. And fun versus philanthropy. It's so heartening to be in a group like this, in which so many of you have turned your lives to philanthropy. Well, my undergraduates and the people I work with haven't discovered this, so we actually have people do something altruistic and do something fun, and contrast it. And what you find is when you do something fun, it has a square wave walk set. When you do something philanthropic to help another person, it lasts and it lasts. So those are examples of positive interventions.So the next to last thing I want to say is: we're interested in how much life satisfaction people have. This is really what you're about. And that's our target variable. And we ask the question as a function of the three different lives, how much life satisfaction do you get? So we ask — and we've done this in 15 replications, involving thousands of people: To what extent does the pursuit of pleasure, the pursuit of positive emotion, the pleasant life, the pursuit of engagement, time stopping for you, and the pursuit of meaning contribute to life satisfaction?And our results surprised us; they were backward of what we thought. It turns out the pursuit of pleasure has almost no contribution to life satisfaction. The pursuit of meaning is the strongest. The pursuit of engagement is also very strong. Where pleasure matters is if you have both engagement and you have meaning, then pleasure's the whipped cream and the cherry. Which is to say, the full life — the sum is greater than the parts, if you've got all three. Conversely, if you have none of the three, the empty life, the sum is less than the parts.And what we're asking now is: Does the very same relationship — physical health, morbidity, how long you live and productivity — follow the same relationship? That is, in a corporation, is productivity a function of positive emotion, engagement and meaning? Is health a function of positive engagement, of pleasure, and of meaning in life? And there is reason to think the answer to both of those may well be yes.So, Chris said that the last speaker had a chance to try to integrate what he heard, and so this was amazing for me. I've never been in a gathering like this. I've never seen speakers stretch beyond themselves so much, which was one of the remarkable things. But I found that the problems of psychology seemed to be parallel to the problems of technology, entertainment and design in the following way: we all know that technology, entertainment and design have been and can be used for destructive purposes. We also know that technology, entertainment and design can be used to relieve misery. And by the way, the distinction between relieving misery and building happiness is extremely important. I thought, when I first became a therapist 30 years ago, that if I was good enough to make someone not depressed, not anxious, not angry, that I'd make them happy. And I never found that; I found the best you could ever do was to get to zero; that they were empty.And it turns out the skills of happiness, the skills of the pleasant life, the skills of engagement, the skills of meaning, are different from the skills of relieving misery. And so, the parallel thing holds with technology, entertainment and design, I believe. That is, it is possible for these three drivers of our world to increase happiness, to increase positive emotion. And that's typically how they've been used. But once you fractionate happiness the way I do — not just positive emotion, that's not nearly enough — there's flow in life, and there's meaning in life. As Laura Lee told us, design and, I believe, entertainment and technology, can be used to increase meaning engagement in life as well.So in conclusion, the eleventh reason for optimism, in addition to the space elevator, is that I think with technology, entertainment and design, we can actually increase the amount of tonnage of human happiness on the planet. And if technology can, in the next decade or two, increase the pleasant life, the good life and the meaningful life, it will be good enough. If entertainment can be diverted to also increase positive emotion, meaning eudaemonia, it will be good enough. And if design can increase positive emotion, eudaemonia, and flow and meaning, what we're all doing together will become good enough.Thank you.(Applause)

And best of all, we were able,
in the last 50 years,

00:03:54.973 --> 00:03:58.802
to invent drug treatments
and psychological treatments.

00:03:59.680 --> 00:04:02.934
And then we were able
to test them rigorously,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:06.251
in random-assignment,
placebo-controlled designs,

00:04:06.275 --> 00:04:08.527
throw out the things that didn't work,

00:04:08.551 --> 00:04:10.275
keep the things that actively did.

00:04:10.654 --> 00:04:13.817
The conclusion of that is,

00:04:13.841 --> 00:04:16.934
psychology and psychiatry
of the last 60 years

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:22.111
can actually claim that we can make
miserable people less miserable.

00:04:22.616 --> 00:04:24.768
And I think that's terrific.

00:04:24.792 --> 00:04:26.178
I'm proud of it.

00:04:29.791 --> 00:04:33.359
But what was not good,
the consequences of that,

00:04:33.473 --> 00:04:34.889
were three things.

00:04:34.913 --> 00:04:36.691
The first was moral;

00:04:36.715 --> 00:04:41.509
that psychologists and psychiatrists
became victimologists, pathologizers;

00:04:41.533 --> 00:04:44.575
that our view of human nature
was that if you were in trouble,

00:04:44.599 --> 00:04:45.996
bricks fell on you.

00:04:46.372 --> 00:04:49.113
And we forgot that people
made choices and decisions.

00:04:49.137 --> 00:04:50.635
We forgot responsibility.

00:04:51.026 --> 00:04:52.701
That was the first cost.

00:04:53.175 --> 00:04:56.934
The second cost was
that we forgot about you people.

00:04:57.479 --> 00:05:01.034
We forgot about improving normal lives.

00:05:01.058 --> 00:05:06.934
We forgot about a mission to make
relatively untroubled people happier,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.738
more fulfilled, more productive.

00:05:09.762 --> 00:05:13.068
And "genius," "high-talent,"
became a dirty word.

00:05:13.485 --> 00:05:15.021
No one works on that.

00:05:15.520 --> 00:05:18.934
And the third problem
about the disease model is,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.239
in our rush to do something
about people in trouble,

00:05:22.263 --> 00:05:25.979
in our rush to do something
about repairing damage,

00:05:27.391 --> 00:05:30.006
it never occurred to us
to develop interventions

00:05:30.030 --> 00:05:33.789
to make people happier --
positive interventions.

00:05:34.293 --> 00:05:36.134
So that was not good.

00:05:36.158 --> 00:05:40.987
And so that's what led people
like Nancy Etcoff, Dan Gilbert,

00:05:41.011 --> 00:05:42.920
Mike Csikszentmihalyi and myself

00:05:42.944 --> 00:05:45.804
to work in something I call,
"positive psychology,"

00:05:45.828 --> 00:05:47.240
which has three aims.

00:05:47.637 --> 00:05:52.523
The first is that psychology
should be just as concerned

00:05:52.547 --> 00:05:55.263
with human strength
as it is with weakness.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:06:00.604
It should be just as concerned
with building strength

00:06:00.628 --> 00:06:02.766
as with repairing damage.

00:06:02.790 --> 00:06:05.473
It should be interested
in the best things in life.

00:06:05.497 --> 00:06:07.371
And it should be just as concerned

00:06:07.395 --> 00:06:11.108
with making the lives
of normal people fulfilling,

00:06:11.132 --> 00:06:15.081
and with genius,
with nurturing high talent.

00:06:16.026 --> 00:06:20.509
So in the last 10 years
and the hope for the future,

00:06:20.533 --> 00:06:23.934
we've seen the beginnings
of a science of positive psychology,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.133
a science of what makes life worth living.

00:06:26.497 --> 00:06:31.042
It turns out that we can measure
different forms of happiness.

00:06:31.066 --> 00:06:34.546
And any of you, for free,
can go to that website --

00:06:34.570 --> 00:06:35.961
[www.authentichappiness.org]

00:06:35.985 --> 00:06:38.464
and take the entire panoply
of tests of happiness.

00:06:38.488 --> 00:06:42.934
You can ask, how do you stack
up for positive emotion, for meaning,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:46.986
for flow, against literally tens
of thousands of other people?

00:06:47.676 --> 00:06:52.934
We created the opposite of the diagnostic
manual of the insanities:

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:58.179
a classification of the strengths
and virtues that looks at the sex ratio,

00:06:58.203 --> 00:07:00.409
how they're defined, how to diagnose them,

00:07:00.433 --> 00:07:03.251
what builds them
and what gets in their way.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:09.397
We found that we could discover
the causation of the positive states,

00:07:09.421 --> 00:07:12.934
the relationship between left
hemispheric activity

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:18.958
and right hemispheric activity,
as a cause of happiness.

00:07:20.458 --> 00:07:23.435
I've spent my life working
on extremely miserable people,

00:07:23.459 --> 00:07:24.846
and I've asked the question:

00:07:24.870 --> 00:07:28.523
How do extremely miserable people
differ from the rest of you?

00:07:28.547 --> 00:07:32.934
And starting about six years ago,
we asked about extremely happy people.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.498
How do they differ from the rest of us?

00:07:35.522 --> 00:07:39.005
It turns out there's one way,
very surprising --

00:07:39.029 --> 00:07:41.697
they're not more religious,
they're not in better shape,

00:07:41.721 --> 00:07:44.809
they don't have more money,
they're not better looking,

00:07:44.833 --> 00:07:47.588
they don't have more good events
and fewer bad events.

00:07:47.612 --> 00:07:51.000
The one way in which they differ:
they're extremely social.

00:07:52.762 --> 00:07:55.463
They don't sit in seminars
on Saturday morning.

00:07:55.487 --> 00:07:59.442
(Laughter)

00:07:59.935 --> 00:08:01.435
They don't spend time alone.

00:08:01.459 --> 00:08:03.657
Each of them is in a romantic relationship

00:08:03.681 --> 00:08:06.829
and each has a rich repertoire of friends.

00:08:06.853 --> 00:08:11.230
But watch out here -- this is merely
correlational data, not causal,

00:08:11.254 --> 00:08:14.852
and it's about happiness
in the first, "Hollywood" sense,

00:08:14.876 --> 00:08:16.088
I'm going to talk about,

00:08:16.112 --> 00:08:20.278
happiness of ebullience
and giggling and good cheer.

00:08:20.302 --> 00:08:23.137
And I'm going to suggest to you
that's not nearly enough,

00:08:23.161 --> 00:08:24.311
in just a moment.

00:08:25.382 --> 00:08:29.763
We found we could begin to look
at interventions over the centuries,

00:08:29.787 --> 00:08:31.580
from the Buddha to Tony Robbins.

00:08:31.604 --> 00:08:36.387
About 120 interventions have been proposed
that allegedly make people happy.

00:08:36.814 --> 00:08:41.436
And we find that we've been able
to manualize many of them,

00:08:41.460 --> 00:08:43.379
and we actually carry out

00:08:43.403 --> 00:08:47.045
random-assignment efficacy
and effectiveness studies.

00:08:47.069 --> 00:08:51.225
That is, which ones actually
make people lastingly happier?

00:08:51.249 --> 00:08:54.476
In a couple of minutes, I'll tell you
about some of those results.

00:08:54.500 --> 00:09:00.934
But the upshot of this is that the mission
I want psychology to have,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:04.445
in addition to its mission
of curing the mentally ill,

00:09:04.469 --> 00:09:08.743
and in addition to its mission of making
miserable people less miserable,

00:09:08.767 --> 00:09:12.338
is, can psychology actually
make people happier?

00:09:12.720 --> 00:09:16.866
And to ask that question -- "happy"
is not a word I use very much --

00:09:17.393 --> 00:09:18.806
we've had to break it down

00:09:18.830 --> 00:09:21.362
into what I think
is askable about "happy."

00:09:21.386 --> 00:09:24.372
And I believe there are three different --

00:09:25.137 --> 00:09:28.420
I call them "different" because different
interventions build them,

00:09:28.444 --> 00:09:30.845
it's possible to have one
rather than the other --

00:09:30.869 --> 00:09:32.846
three different happy lives.

00:09:32.870 --> 00:09:35.987
The first happy life is the pleasant life.

00:09:36.011 --> 00:09:39.396
This is a life in which you have
as much positive emotion

00:09:39.420 --> 00:09:40.934
as you possibly can,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.059
and the skills to amplify it.

00:09:43.083 --> 00:09:45.263
The second is a life of engagement:

00:09:45.287 --> 00:09:50.652
a life in your work, your parenting,
your love, your leisure;

00:09:50.676 --> 00:09:51.982
time stops for you.

00:09:53.100 --> 00:09:55.148
That's what Aristotle was talking about.

00:09:55.172 --> 00:09:57.239
And third, the meaningful life.

00:09:57.263 --> 00:09:59.934
I want to say a little bit
about each of those lives

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.775
and what we know about them.

00:10:01.799 --> 00:10:06.777
The first life is the pleasant life,
and it's simply, as best we can find it,

00:10:06.801 --> 00:10:09.088
it's having as many
of the pleasures as you can,

00:10:09.112 --> 00:10:11.221
as much positive emotion as you can,

00:10:11.511 --> 00:10:17.733
and learning the skills -- savoring,
mindfulness -- that amplify them,

00:10:18.072 --> 00:10:20.934
that stretch them over time and space.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.934
But the pleasant life has three drawbacks,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.466
and it's why positive psychology
is not happy-ology,

00:10:28.490 --> 00:10:30.367
and why it doesn't end here.

00:10:30.839 --> 00:10:33.934
The first drawback is,
it turns out the pleasant life,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.395
your experience of positive emotion,

00:10:36.617 --> 00:10:41.340
is about 50 percent heritable,

00:10:41.364 --> 00:10:44.934
and, in fact, not very modifiable.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:49.497
So the different tricks
that Matthieu and I and others know

00:10:49.521 --> 00:10:53.132
about increasing the amount
of positive emotion in your life

00:10:53.156 --> 00:10:57.132
are 15 to 20 percent tricks,
getting more of it.

00:10:57.454 --> 00:11:01.696
Second is that positive
emotion habituates.

00:11:01.720 --> 00:11:05.520
It habituates rapidly, indeed.

00:11:05.544 --> 00:11:07.914
It's all like French vanilla ice cream:

00:11:07.938 --> 00:11:10.553
the first taste is 100 percent;

00:11:10.577 --> 00:11:12.746
by the time you're down
to the sixth taste,

00:11:12.770 --> 00:11:13.927
it's gone.

00:11:15.615 --> 00:11:18.747
And, as I said,
it's not particularly malleable.

00:11:20.398 --> 00:11:22.265
And this leads to the second life.

00:11:22.289 --> 00:11:24.227
I have to tell you about my friend Len,

00:11:24.251 --> 00:11:30.162
to talk about why positive psychology
is more than positive emotion,

00:11:30.186 --> 00:11:31.934
more than building pleasure.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.934
In two of the three great arenas
of life, by the time Len was 30,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.382
Len was enormously successful.

00:11:38.406 --> 00:11:41.934
The first arena was work.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.594
By the time he was 20,
he was an options trader.

00:11:44.618 --> 00:11:47.045
By the time he was 25,
he was a multimillionaire

00:11:47.069 --> 00:11:49.415
and the head of an options
trading company.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:55.105
Second, in play, he's a national
champion bridge player.

00:11:57.164 --> 00:12:01.934
But in the third great arena of life,
love, Len is an abysmal failure.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:06.900
And the reason he was,
was that Len is a cold fish.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.108
(Laughter)

00:12:10.052 --> 00:12:11.958
Len is an introvert.

00:12:14.490 --> 00:12:17.934
American women said to Len,
when he dated them,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.934
"You're no fun. You don't have
positive emotion. Get lost."

00:12:22.745 --> 00:12:27.934
And Len was wealthy enough to be able
to afford a Park Avenue psychoanalyst,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.702
who for five years tried
to find the sexual trauma

00:12:31.726 --> 00:12:35.152
that had somehow locked
positive emotion inside of him.

00:12:35.695 --> 00:12:38.849
But it turned out there wasn't
any sexual trauma.

00:12:38.873 --> 00:12:41.064
It turned out that --

00:12:41.088 --> 00:12:43.467
Len grew up in Long Island

00:12:43.491 --> 00:12:49.073
and he played football
and watched football, and played bridge.

00:12:50.334 --> 00:12:54.544
Len is in the bottom five percent
of what we call positive affectivities.

00:12:54.568 --> 00:12:56.353
The question is: Is Len unhappy?

00:12:56.616 --> 00:12:58.035
And I want to say, not.

00:12:58.385 --> 00:13:01.344
Contrary to what psychology told us

00:13:01.368 --> 00:13:05.520
about the bottom 50 percent
of the human race in positive affectivity,

00:13:05.544 --> 00:13:08.136
I think Len is one
of the happiest people I know.

00:13:08.160 --> 00:13:10.806
He's not consigned
to the hell of unhappiness,

00:13:10.830 --> 00:13:14.745
and that's because Len, like most of you,

00:13:14.769 --> 00:13:16.831
is enormously capable of flow.

00:13:16.855 --> 00:13:19.829
When he walks onto the floor
of the American Exchange

00:13:19.853 --> 00:13:21.603
at 9:30 in the morning,

00:13:22.116 --> 00:13:23.407
time stops for him.

00:13:23.431 --> 00:13:25.193
And it stops till the closing bell.

00:13:25.217 --> 00:13:28.117
When the first card is played
till 10 days later,

00:13:28.141 --> 00:13:29.499
when the tournament is over,

00:13:29.523 --> 00:13:30.933
time stops for Len.

00:13:31.634 --> 00:13:34.846
And this is indeed
what Mike Csikszentmihalyi

00:13:34.870 --> 00:13:36.772
has been talking about, about flow.

00:13:36.796 --> 00:13:40.173
And it's distinct from pleasure
in a very important way:

00:13:40.197 --> 00:13:45.601
pleasure has raw feel -- you know
it's happening; it's thought and feeling.

00:13:45.625 --> 00:13:48.714
But what Mike told you
yesterday -- during flow ...

00:13:50.877 --> 00:13:52.982
you can't feel anything.

00:13:54.530 --> 00:13:56.181
You're one with the music.

00:13:56.622 --> 00:13:57.875
Time stops.

00:13:57.899 --> 00:13:59.793
You have intense concentration.

00:13:59.817 --> 00:14:04.568
And this is indeed the characteristic
of what we think of as the good life.

00:14:05.060 --> 00:14:07.845
And we think there's a recipe for it,

00:14:07.869 --> 00:14:10.463
and it's knowing what
your highest strengths are --

00:14:10.487 --> 00:14:12.781
again, there's a valid test

00:14:12.805 --> 00:14:15.188
of what your five highest strengths are --

00:14:15.212 --> 00:14:17.941
and then re-crafting your life

00:14:17.965 --> 00:14:21.225
to use them as much as you possibly can.

00:14:21.249 --> 00:14:23.934
Re-crafting your work, your love,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.715
your play, your friendship,
your parenting.

00:14:26.739 --> 00:14:28.319
Just one example.

00:14:29.046 --> 00:14:32.654
One person I worked with
was a bagger at Genuardi's.

00:14:33.114 --> 00:14:34.279
Hated the job.

00:14:34.303 --> 00:14:36.196
She's working her way through college.

00:14:36.727 --> 00:14:39.862
Her highest strength
was social intelligence.

00:14:39.886 --> 00:14:44.601
So she re-crafted bagging
to make the encounter with her

00:14:44.625 --> 00:14:47.396
the social highlight
of every customer's day.

00:14:47.880 --> 00:14:49.596
Now, obviously she failed.

00:14:49.620 --> 00:14:52.934
But what she did was to take
her highest strengths,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.366
and re-craft work to use them
as much as possible.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.306
What you get out of that
is not smiley-ness.

00:14:59.330 --> 00:15:01.233
You don't look like Debbie Reynolds.

00:15:01.257 --> 00:15:02.661
You don't giggle a lot.

00:15:02.685 --> 00:15:05.271
What you get is more absorption.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.032
So, that's the second path.

00:15:08.056 --> 00:15:10.408
The first path, positive emotion;

00:15:10.432 --> 00:15:13.528
the second path is eudaemonian flow;

00:15:13.552 --> 00:15:15.934
and the third path is meaning.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:19.934
This is the most venerable
of the happinesses, traditionally.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.457
And meaning, in this view, consists of --

00:15:23.481 --> 00:15:26.401
very parallel to eudaemonia --

00:15:26.425 --> 00:15:29.988
it consists of knowing
what your highest strengths are,

00:15:30.012 --> 00:15:34.655
and using them to belong to
and in the service of

00:15:34.679 --> 00:15:36.822
something larger than you are.

00:15:38.880 --> 00:15:42.132
I mentioned that for all three
kinds of lives --

00:15:43.205 --> 00:15:46.548
the pleasant life, the good life,
the meaningful life --

00:15:46.572 --> 00:15:48.736
people are now
hard at work on the question:

00:15:48.760 --> 00:15:52.687
Are there things that lastingly
change those lives?

00:15:53.726 --> 00:15:56.725
And the answer seems to be yes.

00:15:56.749 --> 00:15:59.304
And I'll just give you some samples of it.

00:15:59.328 --> 00:16:01.492
It's being done in a rigorous manner.

00:16:01.516 --> 00:16:04.353
It's being done in the same way
that we test drugs

00:16:04.377 --> 00:16:05.986
to see what really works.

00:16:06.471 --> 00:16:11.284
So we do random-assignment,
placebo-controlled,

00:16:11.308 --> 00:16:14.155
long-term studies
of different interventions.

00:16:14.179 --> 00:16:18.684
Just to sample the kind of interventions
that we find have an effect:

00:16:18.708 --> 00:16:21.934
when we teach people
about the pleasant life,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.934
how to have more pleasure in your life,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.977
one of your assignments
is to take the mindfulness skills,

00:16:28.001 --> 00:16:30.416
the savoring skills,

00:16:30.440 --> 00:16:33.198
and you're assigned
to design a beautiful day.

00:16:34.131 --> 00:16:39.145
Next Saturday, set a day aside,
design yourself a beautiful day,

00:16:39.169 --> 00:16:43.363
and use savoring and mindfulness
to enhance those pleasures.

00:16:43.387 --> 00:16:47.888
And we can show in that way
that the pleasant life is enhanced.

00:16:49.696 --> 00:16:50.920
Gratitude visit.

00:16:53.041 --> 00:16:55.697
I want you all to do this
with me now, if you would.

00:16:55.721 --> 00:16:56.969
Close your eyes.

00:16:58.770 --> 00:17:03.114
I'd like you to remember someone

00:17:03.138 --> 00:17:06.186
who did something enormously important

00:17:06.210 --> 00:17:09.934
that changed your life
in a good direction,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.891
and who you never properly thanked.

00:17:13.105 --> 00:17:14.594
The person has to be alive.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.121
Now, OK, you can open your eyes.

00:17:18.145 --> 00:17:20.479
I hope all of you have such a person.

00:17:20.503 --> 00:17:24.101
Your assignment, when you're learning
the gratitude visit,

00:17:24.125 --> 00:17:27.774
is to write a 300-word
testimonial to that person,

00:17:28.492 --> 00:17:30.421
call them on the phone in Phoenix,

00:17:31.119 --> 00:17:33.766
ask if you can visit, don't tell them why.

00:17:33.790 --> 00:17:35.293
Show up at their door,

00:17:36.257 --> 00:17:40.254
you read the testimonial --
everyone weeps when this happens.

00:17:41.537 --> 00:17:44.439
And what happens is, when we test people

00:17:44.463 --> 00:17:47.582
one week later, a month later,
three months later,

00:17:47.606 --> 00:17:50.264
they're both happier and less depressed.

00:17:51.680 --> 00:17:54.015
Another example is a strengths date,

00:17:54.039 --> 00:17:58.221
in which we get couples to identify
their highest strengths

00:17:58.245 --> 00:17:59.620
on the strengths test,

00:17:59.644 --> 00:18:04.725
and then to design an evening
in which they both use their strengths.

00:18:04.749 --> 00:18:08.242
We find this is a strengthener
of relationships.

00:18:08.746 --> 00:18:10.720
And fun versus philanthropy.

00:18:10.744 --> 00:18:13.464
It's so heartening
to be in a group like this,

00:18:13.488 --> 00:18:17.088
in which so many of you have turned
your lives to philanthropy.

00:18:17.112 --> 00:18:20.770
Well, my undergraduates and the people
I work with haven't discovered this,

00:18:20.794 --> 00:18:23.602
so we actually have people
do something altruistic

00:18:24.380 --> 00:18:26.044
and do something fun,

00:18:26.155 --> 00:18:27.309
and contrast it.

00:18:27.333 --> 00:18:29.934
And what you find
is when you do something fun,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.847
it has a square wave walk set.

00:18:31.871 --> 00:18:35.507
When you do something philanthropic
to help another person,

00:18:35.531 --> 00:18:37.620
it lasts and it lasts.

00:18:38.484 --> 00:18:42.004
So those are examples
of positive interventions.

00:18:42.638 --> 00:18:46.054
So the next to last thing
I want to say is:

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:50.077
we're interested in how much
life satisfaction people have.

00:18:50.101 --> 00:18:52.041
This is really what you're about.

00:18:52.065 --> 00:18:53.934
And that's our target variable.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:57.934
And we ask the question as a function
of the three different lives,

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:00.174
how much life satisfaction do you get?

00:19:00.705 --> 00:19:03.810
So we ask -- and we've done this
in 15 replications,

00:19:03.834 --> 00:19:06.212
involving thousands of people:

00:19:06.236 --> 00:19:08.731
To what extent does
the pursuit of pleasure,

00:19:08.755 --> 00:19:10.527
the pursuit of positive emotion,

00:19:11.101 --> 00:19:12.275
the pleasant life,

00:19:12.299 --> 00:19:15.707
the pursuit of engagement,
time stopping for you,

00:19:15.731 --> 00:19:19.105
and the pursuit of meaning
contribute to life satisfaction?

00:19:19.129 --> 00:19:22.723
And our results surprised us;
they were backward of what we thought.

00:19:22.747 --> 00:19:26.251
It turns out the pursuit of pleasure
has almost no contribution

00:19:26.275 --> 00:19:27.934
to life satisfaction.

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:30.487
The pursuit of meaning is the strongest.

00:19:30.511 --> 00:19:34.658
The pursuit of engagement
is also very strong.

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:39.592
Where pleasure matters
is if you have both engagement

00:19:39.616 --> 00:19:41.225
and you have meaning,

00:19:41.249 --> 00:19:43.538
then pleasure's the whipped
cream and the cherry.

00:19:43.562 --> 00:19:50.080
Which is to say, the full life --
the sum is greater than the parts,

00:19:50.104 --> 00:19:51.510
if you've got all three.

00:19:51.534 --> 00:19:54.776
Conversely, if you have none
of the three, the empty life,

00:19:54.800 --> 00:19:56.457
the sum is less than the parts.

00:19:56.481 --> 00:20:00.732
And what we're asking now is:
Does the very same relationship --

00:20:00.756 --> 00:20:05.699
physical health, morbidity,
how long you live and productivity --

00:20:05.723 --> 00:20:07.132
follow the same relationship?

00:20:07.156 --> 00:20:09.634
That is, in a corporation,

00:20:09.658 --> 00:20:15.497
is productivity a function of positive
emotion, engagement and meaning?

00:20:15.521 --> 00:20:18.688
Is health a function
of positive engagement,

00:20:18.712 --> 00:20:21.449
of pleasure, and of meaning in life?

00:20:21.473 --> 00:20:25.688
And there is reason to think the answer
to both of those may well be yes.

00:20:28.162 --> 00:20:32.591
So, Chris said that the last
speaker had a chance

00:20:32.615 --> 00:20:35.036
to try to integrate what he heard,

00:20:35.060 --> 00:20:36.766
and so this was amazing for me.

00:20:36.790 --> 00:20:40.084
I've never been in a gathering like this.

00:20:40.759 --> 00:20:44.483
I've never seen speakers stretch
beyond themselves so much,

00:20:44.507 --> 00:20:46.579
which was one of the remarkable things.

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:50.934
But I found that the problems
of psychology seemed to be parallel

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:55.173
to the problems of technology,
entertainment and design

00:20:55.197 --> 00:20:56.672
in the following way:

00:20:56.696 --> 00:21:00.178
we all know that technology,
entertainment and design

00:21:00.202 --> 00:21:05.202
have been and can be used
for destructive purposes.

00:21:06.329 --> 00:21:10.484
We also know that technology,
entertainment and design

00:21:10.508 --> 00:21:13.027
can be used to relieve misery.

00:21:13.509 --> 00:21:16.934
And by the way, the distinction
between relieving misery

00:21:16.958 --> 00:21:19.934
and building happiness
is extremely important.

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:23.569
I thought, when I first became
a therapist 30 years ago,

00:21:23.593 --> 00:21:28.934
that if I was good enough
to make someone not depressed,

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:32.006
not anxious, not angry,

00:21:32.825 --> 00:21:34.291
that I'd make them happy.

00:21:34.860 --> 00:21:36.235
And I never found that;

00:21:36.259 --> 00:21:38.281
I found the best you could ever do

00:21:38.305 --> 00:21:39.707
was to get to zero;

00:21:40.308 --> 00:21:41.522
that they were empty.

00:21:41.546 --> 00:21:47.152
And it turns out the skills of happiness,
the skills of the pleasant life,

00:21:47.176 --> 00:21:49.547
the skills of engagement,
the skills of meaning,

00:21:49.571 --> 00:21:53.722
are different from the skills
of relieving misery.

00:21:54.293 --> 00:21:59.664
And so, the parallel thing holds
with technology, entertainment

00:21:59.688 --> 00:22:01.261
and design, I believe.

00:22:01.285 --> 00:22:08.164
That is, it is possible
for these three drivers of our world

00:22:08.188 --> 00:22:10.403
to increase happiness,

00:22:10.716 --> 00:22:13.604
to increase positive emotion.

00:22:13.628 --> 00:22:15.815
And that's typically
how they've been used.

00:22:15.839 --> 00:22:18.449
But once you fractionate
happiness the way I do --

00:22:18.861 --> 00:22:21.934
not just positive emotion,
that's not nearly enough --

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:25.091
there's flow in life,
and there's meaning in life.

00:22:25.464 --> 00:22:26.934
As Laura Lee told us,

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:30.626
design and, I believe,
entertainment and technology,

00:22:30.650 --> 00:22:35.381
can be used to increase meaning
engagement in life as well.

00:22:35.405 --> 00:22:37.025
So in conclusion,

00:22:37.049 --> 00:22:39.476
the eleventh reason for optimism,

00:22:39.500 --> 00:22:42.675
in addition to the space elevator,

00:22:42.699 --> 00:22:47.830
is that I think with technology,
entertainment and design,

00:22:47.854 --> 00:22:51.602
we can actually increase
the amount of tonnage

00:22:51.626 --> 00:22:53.876
of human happiness on the planet.

00:22:54.479 --> 00:22:58.742
And if technology can,
in the next decade or two,

00:22:58.766 --> 00:23:02.630
increase the pleasant life,
the good life and the meaningful life,

00:23:02.654 --> 00:23:04.144
it will be good enough.

00:23:04.168 --> 00:23:09.773
If entertainment can be diverted
to also increase positive emotion,

00:23:09.925 --> 00:23:13.019
meaning eudaemonia,

00:23:13.043 --> 00:23:14.482
it will be good enough.

00:23:14.506 --> 00:23:19.072
And if design can increase
positive emotion,

00:23:20.540 --> 00:23:23.535
eudaemonia, and flow and meaning,

00:23:23.559 --> 00:23:27.098
what we're all doing together
will become good enough.

00:23:27.122 --> 00:23:28.301
Thank you.

00:23:28.325 --> 00:23:34.127
(Applause)

title: The wonder of Zulu wire art
transcript: The decorative use of wire in southern Africa dates back hundreds of years. But modernization actually brought communication and a whole new material, in the form of telephone wire. Rural to urban migration meant that newfound industrial materials started to replace hard-to-come-by natural grasses.So, here you can see the change from use — starting to use contemporary materials. These pieces date back from the '40s to the late '50s. In the '90s, my interest and passion for transitional art forms led me to a new form, which came from a squatter camp outside Durban.And I got the opportunity to start working with this community at that point, and started developing, really, and mentoring them in terms of scale, in terms of the design. And the project soon grew from five to 50 weavers in about a year. Soon we had outgrown the scrap yards, what they could provide, so we coerced a wire manufacturer to help us, and not only to supply the materials on bobbins, but to produce to our color specifications.At the same time, I was thinking, well, there's lots of possibility here to produce contemporary products, away from the ethnic, a little bit more contemporary. So I developed a whole range around — mass-produced range — that obviously fitted into a much higher-end decor market that could be exported and also service our local market.We started experimenting, as you can see, in terms of shapes, forms. The scale became very important, and it's become our pet project. It's successful, it's been running for 12 years. And we supply the Conran shops, and Donna Karan, and so it's kind of great.This is our group, our main group of weavers. They come on a weekly basis to Durban. They all have bank accounts. They've all moved back to the rural area where they came from. It's a weekly turnaround of production. This is the community that I originally showed you the slide of. And that's also modernized today, and it's supporting work for 300 weavers. And the rest says it all.Thank you very much. (Applause)

title: On humanity
transcript: My search is always to find ways to chronicle, to share and to document stories about people, just everyday people. Stories that offer transformation, that lean into transcendence, but that are never sentimental, that never look away from the darkest things about us. Because I really believe that we're never more beautiful than when we're most ugly. Because that's really the moment we really know what we're made of. As Chris said, I grew up in Nigeria with a whole generation — in the '80s — of students who were protesting a military dictatorship, which has finally ended. So it wasn't just me, there was a whole generation of us.But what I've come to learn is that the world is never saved in grand messianic gestures, but in the simple accumulation of gentle, soft, almost invisible acts of compassion, everyday acts of compassion. In South Africa, they have a phrase called Ubuntu. Ubuntu comes out of a philosophy that says, the only way for me to be human is for you to reflect my humanity back at me. But if you're like me, my humanity is more like a window. I don't really see it, I don't pay attention to it until there's, you know, like a bug that's dead on the window. Then suddenly I see it, and usually, it's never good. It's usually when I'm cussing in traffic at someone who is trying to drive their car and drink coffee and send emails and make notes. So what Ubuntu really says is that there is no way for us to be human without other people. It's really very simple, but really very complicated.So, I thought I should start with some stories. I should tell you some stories about remarkable people, so I thought I'd start with my mother. (Laughter) And she was dark, too. My mother was English. My parents met in Oxford in the '50s, and my mother moved to Nigeria and lived there. She was five foot two, very feisty and very English. This is how English my mother is — or was, she just passed. She came out to California, to Los Angeles, to visit me, and we went to Malibu, which she thought was very disappointing. (Laughter) And then we went to a fish restaurant, and we had Chad, the surfer dude, serving us, and he came up and my mother said, "Do you have any specials, young man?" And Chad says, "Sure, like, we have this, like, salmon, that's, like, rolled in this, like, wasabi, like, crust. It's totally rad." And my mother turned to me and said, "What language is he speaking?" (Laughter) I said, "English, mum." And she shook her head and said, "Oh, these Americans. We gave them a language, why don't they use it?" (Laughter)So, this woman, who converted from the Church of England to Catholicism when she married my father — and there's no one more rabid than a Catholic convert — decided to teach in the rural areas in Nigeria, particularly among Igbo women, the Billings ovulation method, which was the only approved birth control by the Catholic Church. But her Igbo wasn't too good. So she took me along to translate. I was seven. (Laughter) So, here are these women, who never discuss their period with their husbands, and here I am telling them, "Well, how often do you get your period?" (Laughter) And, "Do you notice any discharges?" (Laughter) And, "How swollen is your vulva?" (Laughter) She never would have thought of herself as a feminist, my mother, but she always used to say, "Anything a man can do, I can fix." (Applause) And when my father complained about this situation, where she's taking a seven-year-old boy to teach this birth control, you know, he used to say, "Oh, you're turning him into — you're teaching him how to be a woman." My mother said, "Someone has to." (Laughter)This woman — during the Biafran war, we were caught in the war. It was my mother with five little children. It takes her one year, through refugee camp after refugee camp, to make her way to an airstrip where we can fly out of the country. At every single refugee camp, she has to face off soldiers who want to take my elder brother Mark, who was nine, and make him a boy soldier. Can you imagine this five-foot-two woman, standing up to men with guns who want to kill us? All through that one year, my mother never cried one time, not once. But when we were in Lisbon, in the airport, about to fly to England, this woman saw my mother wearing this dress, which had been washed so many times it was basically see through, with five really hungry-looking kids, came over and asked her what had happened. And she told this woman. And so this woman emptied out her suitcase and gave all of her clothes to my mother, and to us, and the toys of her kids, who didn't like that very much, but — (Laughter) — that was the only time she cried. And I remember years later, I was writing about my mother, and I asked her, "Why did you cry then?" And she said, "You know, you can steel your heart against any kind of trouble, any kind of horror. But the simple act of kindness from a complete stranger will unstitch you."The old women in my father's village, after this war had happened, memorized the names of every dead person, and they would sing these dirges, made up of these names. Dirges so melancholic that they would scorch you. And they would sing them only when they planted the rice, as though they were seeding the hearts of the dead into the rice. But when it came for harvest time, they would sing these joyful songs, that were made up of the names of every child who had been born that year. And then the next planting season, when they sang the dirge, they would remove as many names of the dead that equaled as many people that were born. And in this way, these women enacted a lot of transformation, beautiful transformation.Did you know, that before the genocide in Rwanda, the word for rape and the word for marriage was the same one? But today, women are rebuilding Rwanda. Did you also know that after apartheid, when the new government went into the parliament houses, there were no female toilets in the building? Which would seem to suggest that apartheid was entirely the business of men. All of this to say, that despite the horror, and despite the death, women are never really counted. Their humanity never seems to matter very much to us.When I was growing up in Nigeria — and I shouldn't say Nigeria, because that's too general, but in Afikpo, the Igbo part of the country where I'm from — there were always rites of passage for young men. Men were taught to be men in the ways in which we are not women, that's essentially what it is. And a lot of rituals involved killing, killing little animals, progressing along, so when I turned 13 — and, I mean, it made sense, it was an agrarian community, somebody had to kill the animals, there was no Whole Foods you could go and get kangaroo steak at — so when I turned 13, it was my turn now to kill a goat. And I was this weird, sensitive kid, who couldn't really do it, but I had to do it. And I was supposed to do this alone. But a friend of mine, called Emmanuel, who was significantly older than me, who'd been a boy soldier during the Biafran war, decided to come with me. Which sort of made me feel good, because he'd seen a lot of things. Now, when I was growing up, he used to tell me stories about how he used to bayonet people, and their intestines would fall out, but they would keep running. So, this guy comes with me. And I don't know if you've ever heard a goat, or seen one — they sound like human beings, that's why we call tragedies "a song of a goat." My friend Brad Kessler says that we didn't become human until we started keeping goats. Anyway, a goat's eyes are like a child's eyes. So when I tried to kill this goat and I couldn't, Emmanuel bent down, he puts his hand over the mouth of the goat, covers its eyes, so I don't have to look into them, while I kill the goat. It didn't seem like a lot, for this guy who'd seen so much, and to whom the killing of a goat must have seemed such a quotidian experience, still found it in himself to try to protect me. I was a wimp. I cried for a very long time. And afterwards, he didn't say a word. He just sat there watching me cry for an hour. And then afterwards he said to me, "It will always be difficult, but if you cry like this every time, you will die of heartbreak. Just know that it is enough sometimes to know that it is difficult." Of course, talking about goats makes me think of sheep, and not in good ways. (Laughter)So, I was born two days after Christmas. So growing up, you know, I had a cake and everything, but I never got any presents, because, born two days after Christmas. So, I was about nine, and my uncle had just come back from Germany, and we had the Catholic priest over, my mother was entertaining him with tea. And my uncle suddenly says, "Where are Chris' presents?" And my mother said, "Don't talk about that in front of guests." But he was desperate to show that he'd just come back, so he summoned me up, and he said, "Go into the bedroom, my bedroom. Take anything you want out of the suitcase. It's your birthday present." I'm sure he thought I'd take a book or a shirt, but I found an inflatable sheep. (Laughter) So, I blew it up and ran into the living room, my finger where it shouldn't have been, I was waving this buzzing sheep around, and my mother looked like she was going to die of shock. (Laughter) And Father McGetrick was completely unflustered, just stirred his tea and looked at my mother and said, "It's all right Daphne, I'm Scottish." (Laughter) (Applause)My last days in prison, the last 18 months, my cellmate — for the last year, the first year of the last 18 months — my cellmate was 14 years old. The name was John James, and in those days, if a family member committed a crime, the military would hold you as ransom till your family turned themselves in. So, here was this 14-year-old kid on death row. And not everybody on death row was a political prisoner. There were some really bad people there. And he had smuggled in two comics, two comic books — "Spiderman" and "X-Men." He was obsessed. And when he got tired of reading them, he started to teach the men in death row how to read, with these comic books. And so, I remember night after night, you'd hear all these men, these really hardened criminals, huddled around John James, reciting, "Take that, Spidey!" (Laughter) It's incredible. I was really worried. He didn't know what death row meant. I'd been there twice, and I was terribly afraid that I was going to die. And he would always laugh, and say, "Come on, man, we'll make it out." Then I'd say, "How do you know?" And he said, "Oh, I heard it on the grapevine." They killed him. They handcuffed him to a chair, and they tacked his penis to a table with a six-inch nail, then left him there to bleed to death. That's how I ended up in solitary, because I let my feelings be known. All around us, everywhere, there are people like this.The Igbo used to say that they built their own gods. They would come together as a community, and they would express a wish. And their wish would then be brought to a priest, who would find a ritual object, and the appropriate sacrifices would be made, and the shrine would be built for the god. But if the god became unruly and began to ask for human sacrifice, the Igbos would destroy the god. They would knock down the shrine, and they would stop saying the god's name. This is how they came to reclaim their humanity. Every day, all of us here, we're building gods that have gone rampant, and it's time we started knocking them down and forgetting their names. It doesn't require a tremendous thing. All it requires is to recognize among us, every day — the few of us that can see — are surrounded by people like the ones I've told you.There are some of you in this room, amazing people, who offer all of us the mirror to our own humanity. I want to end with a poem by an American poet called Lucille Clifton. The poem is called "Libation," and it's for my friend Vusi who is in the audience here somewhere. "Libation, North Carolina, 1999. I offer to this ground, this gin. I imagine an old man crying here, out of the sight of the overseer. He pushes his tongue through a hole where his tooth would be, if he were whole. It aches in that space where his tooth would be, where his land would be, his house, his wife, his son, his beautiful daughter. He wipes sorrow from his face, and puts his thirsty finger to his thirsty tongue, and tastes the salt. I call a name that could be his. This is for you, old man. This gin, this salty earth." Thank you. (Applause)
