00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
The Internet, the Web as we know it,

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.958
the kind of Web -- the things we're all talking about --

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:20.958
is already less than 5,000 days old.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:24.958
So all of the things that we've seen come about,

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
starting, say, with satellite images of the whole Earth,

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
which we couldn't even imagine happening before,

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:34.958
all these things rolling into our lives,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:39.958
just this abundance of things that are right before us,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
sitting in front of our laptop, or our desktop.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
This kind of cornucopia of stuff

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:49.958
just coming and never ending is amazing, and we're not amazed.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:53.958
It's really amazing that all this stuff is here.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:54.958
(Laughter)

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:58.958
It's in 5,000 days, all this stuff has come.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:01.958
And I know that 10 years ago,

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
if I had told you that this was all coming,

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
you would have said that that's impossible.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:11.958
There's simply no economic model that that would be possible.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
And if I told you it was all coming for free,

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
you would say, this is simply -- you're dreaming.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:19.958
You're a Californian utopian. You're a wild-eyed optimist.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
And yet it's here.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
The other thing that we know about it was that 10 years ago,

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
as I looked at what even Wired was talking about,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
we thought it was going to be TV, but better.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:35.958
That was the model. That was what everybody was suggesting

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
was going to be coming.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
And it turns out that that's not what it was.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
First of all, it was impossible, and it's not what it was.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:44.958
And so one of the things that I think we're learning --

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
if you think about, like, Wikipedia,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
it's something that was simply impossible.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:52.958
It's impossible in theory, but possible in practice.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:53.958
And if you take all these things that are impossible,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:57.958
I think one of the things that we're learning from this era,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:01.958
from this last decade, is that we have to get good at believing in the impossible,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
because we're unprepared for it.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:07.958
So, I'm curious about what's going to happen in the next 5,000 days.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
But if that's happened in the last 5,000 days,

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
what's going to happen in the next 5,000 days?

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
So, I have a kind of a simple story,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
and it suggests that what we want to think about is this thing that we're making,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
this thing that has happened in 5,000 days --

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
that's all these computers, all these handhelds,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:27.958
all these cell phones, all these laptops, all these servers --

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:31.958
basically what we're getting out of all these connections

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
is we're getting one machine.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:37.958
If there is only one machine, and our little handhelds and devices

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
are actually just little windows into those machines,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:45.958
but that we're basically constructing a single, global machine.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
And so I began to think about that.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
And it turned out that this machine happens to be

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
the most reliable machine that we've ever made.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
It has not crashed; it's running uninterrupted.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
And there's almost no other machine that we've ever made

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.958
that runs the number of hours, the number of days.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
5,000 days without interruption -- that's just unbelievable.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
And of course, the Internet is longer than just 5,000 days;

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
the Web is only 5,000 days.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:15.958
So, I was trying to basically make measurements.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
What are the dimensions of this machine?

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:22.958
And I started off by calculating how many billions of clicks there are

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
all around the globe on all the computers.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
And there is a 100 billion clicks per day.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:33.958
And there's 55 trillion links between all the Web pages of the world.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
And so I began thinking more about other kinds of dimensions,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:41.958
and I made a quick list. Was it Chris Jordan, the photographer,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:45.958
talking about numbers being so large that they're meaningless?

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
Well, here's a list of them. They're hard to tell,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
but there's one billion PC chips on the Internet,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
if you count all the chips in all the computers on the Internet.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
There's two million emails per second.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
So it's a very big number.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
It's just a huge machine,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:03.958
and it uses five percent of the global electricity on the planet.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:04.958
So here's the specifications,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
just as if you were to make up a spec sheet for it:

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:10.958
170 quadrillion transistors, 55 trillion links,

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
emails running at two megahertz itself,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
31 kilohertz text messaging,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:19.958
246 exabyte storage. That's a big disk.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
That's a lot of storage, memory. Nine exabyte RAM.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:26.958
And the total traffic on this

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
is running at seven terabytes per second.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Brewster was saying the Library of Congress is about twenty terabytes.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
So every second, half of the Library of Congress

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:39.958
is swooshing around in this machine. It's a big machine.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:43.958
So I did something else. I figured out 100 billion clicks per day,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
55 trillion links is almost the same

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
as the number of synapses in your brain.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
A quadrillion transistors is almost the same

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
as the number of neurons in your brain.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
So to a first approximation, we have these things --

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
twenty petahertz synapse firings.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
Of course, the memory is really huge.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:05.958
But to a first approximation, the size of this machine is the size --

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:10.958
and its complexity, kind of -- to your brain.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:14.958
Because in fact, that's how your brain works -- in kind of the same way that the Web works.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
However, your brain isn't doubling every two years.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:23.958
So if we say this machine right now that we've made

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
is about one HB, one human brain,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
if we look at the rate that this is increasing,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:34.958
30 years from now, there'll be six billion HBs.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
So by the year 2040, the total processing of this machine

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
will exceed a total processing power of humanity,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
in raw bits and stuff. And this is, I think, where

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:49.958
Ray Kurzweil and others get this little chart saying that we're going to cross.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:55.958
So, what about that? Well, here's a couple of things.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
I have three kind of general things

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
I would like to say, three consequences of this.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:07.958
First, that basically what this machine is doing is embodying.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
We're giving it a body. And that's what we're going to do

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
in the next 5,000 days -- we're going to give this machine a body.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And the second thing is, we're going to restructure its architecture.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
And thirdly, we're going to become completely codependent upon it.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
So let me go through those three things.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
First of all, we have all these things in our hands.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
We think they're all separate devices,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
but in fact, every screen in the world

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
is looking into the one machine.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
These are all basically portals into that one machine.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:39.958
The second thing is that -- some people call this the cloud,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
and you're kind of touching the cloud with this.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:45.958
And so in some ways, all you really need is a cloudbook.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
And the cloudbook doesn't have any storage.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
It's wireless. It's always connected.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
There's many things about it. It becomes very simple,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
and basically what you're doing is you're just touching the machine,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
you're touching the cloud and you're going to compute that way.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
So the machine is computing.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:01.958
And in some ways, it's sort of back

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
to the kind of old idea of centralized computing.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
But everything, all the cameras, and the microphones,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and the sensors in cars

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
and everything is connected to this machine.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
And everything will go through the Web.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
And we're seeing that already with, say, phones.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
Right now, phones don't go through the Web,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
but they are beginning to, and they will.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
And if you imagine what, say, just as an example, what Google Labs has

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:31.958
in terms of experiments with Google Docs, Google Spreadsheets, blah, blah, blah --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
all these things are going to become Web based.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
They're going through the machine.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And I am suggesting that every bit will be owned by the Web.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Right now, it's not. If you do spreadsheets and things at work,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
a Word document, they aren't on the Web,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
but they are going to be. They're going to be part of this machine.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
They're going to speak the Web language.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
They're going to talk to the machine.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
The Web, in some sense, is kind of like a black hole

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
that's sucking up everything into it.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:03.958
And so every thing will be part of the Web.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:08.958
So every item, every artifact that we make, will have embedded in it

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
some little sliver of Web-ness and connection,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
and it will be part of this machine,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
so that our environment -- kind of in that ubiquitous computing sense --

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:21.958
our environment becomes the Web. Everything is connected.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Now, with RFIDs and other things -- whatever technology it is,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
it doesn't really matter. The point is that everything

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
will have embedded in it some sensor connecting it to the machine,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and so we have, basically, an Internet of things.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
So you begin to think of a shoe as a chip with heels,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and a car as a chip with wheels,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
because basically most of the cost of manufacturing cars

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:49.958
is the embedded intelligence and electronics in it, and not the materials.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
A lot of people think about the new economy

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
as something that was going to be a disembodied,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
alternative, virtual existence,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
and that we would have the old economy of atoms.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
But in fact, what the new economy really is

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
is the marriage of those two, where we embed the information,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
and the digital nature of things into the material world.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
That's what we're looking forward to. That is where we're going --

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:19.958
this union, this convergence of the atomic and the digital.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
And so one of the consequences of that, I believe,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
is that where we have this sort of spectrum of media right now --

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
TV, film, video -- that basically becomes one media platform.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
And while there's many differences in some senses,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
they will share more and more in common with each other.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:38.958
So that the laws of media, such as the fact that copies have no value,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
the value's in the uncopiable things,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:45.958
the immediacy, the authentication, the personalization.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
The media wants to be liquid.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
The reason why things are free is so that you can manipulate them,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
not so that they are "free" as in "beer," but "free" as in "freedom."

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And the network effects rule,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
meaning that the more you have, the more you get.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
The first fax machine -- the person who bought the first fax machine

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:07.958
was an idiot, because there was nobody to fax to.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.958
But here she became an evangelist, recruiting others

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
to get the fax machines because it made their purchase more valuable.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Those are the effects that we're going to see.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
Attention is the currency.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:23.958
So those laws are going to kind of spread throughout all media.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And the other thing about this embodiment

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
is that there's kind of what I call the McLuhan reversal.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
McLuhan was saying, "Machines are the extensions of the human senses."

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
And I'm saying, "Humans are now going to be

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
the extended senses of the machine," in a certain sense.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:39.958
So we have a trillion eyes, and ears, and touches,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
through all our digital photographs and cameras.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And we see that in things like Flickr,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
or Photosynth, this program from Microsoft

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:54.958
that will allow you to assemble a view of a touristy place

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:58.958
from the thousands of tourist snapshots of it.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:04.958
In a certain sense, the machine is seeing through the pixels of individual cameras.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:08.958
Now, the second thing that I want to talk about was this idea of restructuring,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
that what the Web is doing is restructuring.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
And I have to warn you, that what we'll talk about is --

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:16.958
I'm going to give my explanation of a term you're hearing, which is a "semantic Web."

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
So first of all, the first stage that we've seen

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
of the Internet was that it was going to link computers.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
And that's what we called the Net; that was the Internet of nets.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And we saw that, where you have all the computers of the world.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And if you remember, it was a kind of green screen with cursors,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
and there was really not much to do, and if you wanted to connect it,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
you connected it from one computer to another computer.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
And what you had to do was -- if you wanted to participate in this,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
you had to share packets of information.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
So you were forwarding on. You didn't have control.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
It wasn't like a telephone system where you had control of a line:

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
you had to share packets.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:54.958
The second stage that we're in now is the idea of linking pages.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
So in the old one, if I wanted to go on to an airline Web page,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:01.958
I went from my computer, to an FTP site, to another airline computer.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:06.958
Now we have pages -- the unit has been resolved into pages,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
so one page links to another page.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
And if I want to go in to book a flight,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:16.958
I go into the airline's flight page, the website of the airline,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
and I'm linking to that page.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And what we're sharing were links, so you had to be kind of open with links.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
You couldn't deny -- if someone wanted to link to you,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
you couldn't stop them. You had to participate in this idea

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
of opening up your pages to be linked by anybody.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
So that's what we were doing.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:37.958
We're now entering to the third stage, which is what I'm talking about,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
and that is where we link the data.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
So, I don't know what the name of this thing is.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
I'm calling it the one machine. But we're linking data.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
So we're going from machine to machine,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
from page to page, and now data to data.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:51.958
So the difference is, is that rather than linking from page to page,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:55.958
we're actually going to link from one idea on a page

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
to another idea, rather than to the other page.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
So every idea is basically being supported --

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
or every item, or every noun -- is being supported by the entire Web.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:09.958
It's being resolved at the level of items, or ideas, or words, if you want.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:13.958
So besides physically coming out again into this idea

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
that it's not just virtual, it's actually going out to things.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
So something will resolve down to the information

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
about a particular person, so every person will have a unique ID.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Every person, every item will have a something

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
that will be very specific, and will link

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
to a specific representation of that idea or item.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
So now, in this new one, when I link to it,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:41.958
I would link to my particular flight, my particular seat.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
And so, giving an example of this thing,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
I live in Pacifica, rather than -- right now Pacifica

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
is just sort of a name on the Web somewhere.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
The Web doesn't know that that is actually a town,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
and that it's a specific town that I live in,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
but that's what we're going to be talking about.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
It's going to link directly to --

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
it will know, the Web will be able to read itself

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
and know that that actually is a place,

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
and that whenever it sees that word, "Pacifica,"

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:06.958
it knows that it actually has a place,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
latitude, longitude, a certain population.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
So here are some of the technical terms, all three-letter things,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
that you'll see a lot more of.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:19.958
All these things are about enabling this idea of linking to the data.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
So I'll give you one kind of an example.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
There's like a billion social sites on the Web.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
Each time you go into there, you have to tell it again who you are

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:30.958
and all your friends are.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
Why should you be doing that? You should just do that once,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
and it should know who all your friends are.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
So that's what you want, is all your friends are identified,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
and you should just carry these relationships around.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
All this data about you should just be conveyed,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
and you should do it once and that's all that should happen.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
And you should have all the networks

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
of all the relationships between those pieces of data.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:54.958
That's what we're moving into -- where it sort of knows these things down to that level.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
A semantic Web, Web 3.0, giant global graph --

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
we're kind of trying out what we want to call this thing.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
But what's it's doing is sharing data.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
So you have to be open to having your data shared, which is a much bigger step

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
than just sharing your Web page, or your computer.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
And all these things that are going to be on this

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
are not just pages, they are things.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
Everything we've described, every artifact or place,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
will be a specific representation,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:27.958
will have a specific character that can be linked to directly.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
So we have this database of things.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:33.958
And so there's actually a fourth thing that we have not get to,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
that we won't see in the next 10 years, or 5,000 days,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:40.958
but I think that's where we're going to. And as the Internet of things --

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:44.958
where I'm linking directly to the particular things of my seat on the plane --

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
that that physical thing becomes part of the Web.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
And so we are in the middle of this thing

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
that's completely linked, down to every object

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
in the little sliver of a connection that it has.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
So, the last thing I want to talk about is this idea

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
that we're going to be codependent.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:03.958
It's always going to be there, and the closer it is, the better.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
If you allow Google to, it will tell you your search history.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
And I found out by looking at it

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
that I search most at 11 o'clock in the morning.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
So I am open, and being transparent to that.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:20.958
And I think total personalization in this new world will require total transparency.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
That is going to be the price.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:23.958
If you want to have total personalization,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
you have to be totally transparent.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
Google. I can't remember my phone number, I'll just ask Google.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
We're so dependent on this that I have now gotten to the point

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
where I don't even try to remember things --

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
I'll just Google it. It's easier to do that.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:37.958
And we kind of object at first, saying, "Oh, that's awful."

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
But if we think about the dependency that we have on this other technology,

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
called the alphabet, and writing,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
we're totally dependent on it, and it's transformed culture.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
We cannot imagine ourselves without the alphabet and writing.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
And so in the same way, we're going to not imagine ourselves

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
without this other machine being there.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
And what is happening with this is

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
some kind of AI, but it's not the AI in conscious AI,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
as being an expert, Larry Page told me

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:03.958
that that's what they're trying to do,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
and that's what they're trying to do.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
But when six billion humans are Googling,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
who's searching who? It goes both ways.

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:14.958
So we are the Web, that's what this thing is.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
We are going to be the machine.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:21.958
So the next 5,000 days, it's not going to be the Web and only better.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
Just like it wasn't TV and only better.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
The next 5,000 days, it's not just going to be the Web

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
but only better -- it's going to be something different.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:32.958
And I think it's going to be smarter.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.958
It'll have an intelligence in there, that's not, again, conscious.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:40.958
But it'll anticipate what we're doing, in a good sense.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958
Secondly, it's become much more personalized.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
It will know us, and that's good.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:49.958
And again, the price of that will be transparency.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
And thirdly, it's going to become more ubiquitous

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:56.958
in terms of filling your entire environment, and we will be in the middle of it.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:59.958
And all these devices will be portals into that.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
So the single idea that I wanted to leave with you

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:08.958
is that we have to begin to think about this as not just "the Web, only better,"

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
but a new kind of stage in this development.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
It looks more global. If you take this whole thing,

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
it is a very big machine, very reliable machine,

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
more reliable than its parts.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:22.958
But we can also think about it as kind of a large organism.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:27.958
So we might respond to it more as if this was a whole system,

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
more as if this wasn't a large organism

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:33.958
that we are going to be interacting with. It's a "One."

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
And I don't know what else to call it, than the One.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:37.958
We'll have a better word for it.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
But there's a unity of some sort that's starting to emerge.

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.958
And again, I don't want to talk about consciousness,

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
I want to talk about it just as if it was a little bacteria,

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:48.958
or a volvox, which is what that organism is.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:54.958
So, to do, action, take-away. So, here's what I would say:

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:58.958
there's only one machine, and the Web is its OS.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:02.958
All screens look into the One. No bits will live outside the Web.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:06.958
To share is to gain. Let the One read it.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:07.958
It's going to be machine-readable.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:10.958
You want to make something that the machine can read.

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:15.958
And the One is us. We are in the One.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:17.958
I appreciate your time.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:20.958
(Applause)

title: A computer that works like the brain
transcript: I got my first computer when I was a teenager growing up in Accra, and it was a really cool device. You could play games with it. You could program it in BASIC. And I was fascinated. So I went into the library to figure out how did this thing work. I read about how the CPU is constantly shuffling data back and forth between the memory, the RAM and the ALU, the arithmetic and logic unit. And I thought to myself, this CPU really has to work like crazy just to keep all this data moving through the system.But nobody was really worried about this. When computers were first introduced, they were said to be a million times faster than neurons. People were really excited. They thought they would soon outstrip the capacity of the brain. This is a quote, actually, from Alan Turing: "In 30 years, it will be as easy to ask a computer a question as to ask a person." This was in 1946. And now, in 2007, it's still not true. And so, the question is, why aren't we really seeing this kind of power in computers that we see in the brain?What people didn't realize, and I'm just beginning to realize right now, is that we pay a huge price for the speed that we claim is a big advantage of these computers. Let's take a look at some numbers. This is Blue Gene, the fastest computer in the world. It's got 120,000 processors; they can basically process 10 quadrillion bits of information per second. That's 10 to the sixteenth. And they consume one and a half megawatts of power. So that would be really great, if you could add that to the production capacity in Tanzania. It would really boost the economy. Just to go back to the States, if you translate the amount of power or electricity this computer uses to the amount of households in the States, you get 1,200 households in the U.S. That's how much power this computer uses.Now, let's compare this with the brain. This is a picture of, actually Rory Sayres' girlfriend's brain. Rory is a graduate student at Stanford. He studies the brain using MRI, and he claims that this is the most beautiful brain that he has ever scanned. (Laughter) So that's true love, right there. Now, how much computation does the brain do? I estimate 10 to the 16 bits per second, which is actually about very similar to what Blue Gene does. So that's the question. The question is, how much — they are doing a similar amount of processing, similar amount of data — the question is how much energy or electricity does the brain use? And it's actually as much as your laptop computer: it's just 10 watts. So what we are doing right now with computers with the energy consumed by 1,200 houses, the brain is doing with the energy consumed by your laptop.So the question is, how is the brain able to achieve this kind of efficiency? And let me just summarize. So the bottom line: the brain processes information using 100,000 times less energy than we do right now with this computer technology that we have. How is the brain able to do this? Let's just take a look about how the brain works, and then I'll compare that with how computers work. So, this clip is from the PBS series, "The Secret Life of the Brain." It shows you these cells that process information. They are called neurons. They send little pulses of electricity down their processes to each other, and where they contact each other, those little pulses of electricity can jump from one neuron to the other. That process is called a synapse. You've got this huge network of cells interacting with each other — about 100 million of them, sending about 10 quadrillion of these pulses around every second. And that's basically what's going on in your brain right now as you're watching this.How does that compare with the way computers work? In the computer, you have all the data going through the central processing unit, and any piece of data basically has to go through that bottleneck, whereas in the brain, what you have is these neurons, and the data just really flows through a network of connections among the neurons. There's no bottleneck here. It's really a network in the literal sense of the word. The net is doing the work in the brain. If you just look at these two pictures, these kind of words pop into your mind. This is serial and it's rigid — it's like cars on a freeway, everything has to happen in lockstep — whereas this is parallel and it's fluid. Information processing is very dynamic and adaptive.So I'm not the first to figure this out. This is a quote from Brian Eno: "the problem with computers is that there is not enough Africa in them." (Laughter) Brian actually said this in 1995. And nobody was listening then, but now people are beginning to listen because there's a pressing, technological problem that we face. And I'll just take you through that a little bit in the next few slides.This is — it's actually really this remarkable convergence between the devices that we use to compute in computers, and the devices that our brains use to compute. The devices that computers use are what's called a transistor. This electrode here, called the gate, controls the flow of current from the source to the drain — these two electrodes. And that current, electrical current, is carried by electrons, just like in your house and so on. And what you have here is, when you actually turn on the gate, you get an increase in the amount of current, and you get a steady flow of current. And when you turn off the gate, there's no current flowing through the device. Your computer uses this presence of current to represent a one, and the absence of current to represent a zero.Now, what's happening is that as transistors are getting smaller and smaller and smaller, they no longer behave like this. In fact, they are starting to behave like the device that neurons use to compute, which is called an ion channel. And this is a little protein molecule. I mean, neurons have thousands of these. And it sits in the membrane of the cell and it's got a pore in it. And these are individual potassium ions that are flowing through that pore. Now, this pore can open and close. But, when it's open, because these ions have to line up and flow through, one at a time, you get a kind of sporadic, not steady — it's a sporadic flow of current. And even when you close the pore — which neurons can do, they can open and close these pores to generate electrical activity — even when it's closed, because these ions are so small, they can actually sneak through, a few can sneak through at a time. So, what you have is that when the pore is open, you get some current sometimes. These are your ones, but you've got a few zeros thrown in. And when it's closed, you have a zero, but you have a few ones thrown in.Now, this is starting to happen in transistors. And the reason why that's happening is that, right now, in 2007 — the technology that we are using — a transistor is big enough that several electrons can flow through the channel simultaneously, side by side. In fact, there's about 12 electrons can all be flowing this way. And that means that a transistor corresponds to about 12 ion channels in parallel. Now, in a few years time, by 2015, we will shrink transistors so much. This is what Intel does to keep adding more cores onto the chip. Or your memory sticks that you have now can carry one gigabyte of stuff on them — before, it was 256. Transistors are getting smaller to allow this to happen, and technology has really benefitted from that.But what's happening now is that in 2015, the transistor is going to become so small, that it corresponds to only one electron at a time can flow through that channel, and that corresponds to a single ion channel. And you start having the same kind of traffic jams that you have in the ion channel. The current will turn on and off at random, even when it's supposed to be on. And that means your computer is going to get its ones and zeros mixed up, and that's going to crash your machine.So, we are at the stage where we don't really know how to compute with these kinds of devices. And the only kind of thing — the only thing we know right now that can compute with these kinds of devices are the brain.OK, so a computer picks a specific item of data from memory, it sends it into the processor or the ALU, and then it puts the result back into memory. That's the red path that's highlighted. The way brains work, I told you all, you have got all these neurons. And the way they represent information is they break up that data into little pieces that are represented by pulses and different neurons. So you have all these pieces of data distributed throughout the network. And then the way that you process that data to get a result is that you translate this pattern of activity into a new pattern of activity, just by it flowing through the network. So you set up these connections such that the input pattern just flows and generates the output pattern.What you see here is that there's these redundant connections. So if this piece of data or this piece of the data gets clobbered, it doesn't show up over here, these two pieces can activate the missing part with these redundant connections. So even when you go to these crappy devices where sometimes you want a one and you get a zero, and it doesn't show up, there's redundancy in the network that can actually recover the missing information. It makes the brain inherently robust. What you have here is a system where you store data locally. And it's brittle, because each of these steps has to be flawless, otherwise you lose that data, whereas in the brain, you have a system that stores data in a distributed way, and it's robust.What I want to basically talk about is my dream, which is to build a computer that works like the brain. This is something that we've been working on for the last couple of years. And I'm going to show you a system that we designed to model the retina, which is a piece of brain that lines the inside of your eyeball. We didn't do this by actually writing code, like you do in a computer. In fact, the processing that happens in that little piece of brain is very similar to the kind of processing that computers do when they stream video over the Internet. They want to compress the information — they just want to send the changes, what's new in the image, and so on — and that is how your eyeball is able to squeeze all that information down to your optic nerve, to send to the rest of the brain.Instead of doing this in software, or doing those kinds of algorithms, we went and talked to neurobiologists who have actually reverse engineered that piece of brain that's called the retina. And they figured out all the different cells, and they figured out the network, and we just took that network and we used it as the blueprint for the design of a silicon chip. So now the neurons are represented by little nodes or circuits on the chip, and the connections among the neurons are represented, actually modeled by transistors. And these transistors are behaving essentially just like ion channels behave in the brain. It will give you the same kind of robust architecture that I described.Here is actually what our artificial eye looks like. The retina chip that we designed sits behind this lens here. And the chip — I'm going to show you a video that the silicon retina put out of its output when it was looking at Kareem Zaghloul, who's the student who designed this chip. Let me explain what you're going to see, OK, because it's putting out different kinds of information, it's not as straightforward as a camera. The retina chip extracts four different kinds of information. It extracts regions with dark contrast, which will show up on the video as red. And it extracts regions with white or light contrast, which will show up on the video as green.This is Kareem's dark eyes and that's the white background that you see here. And then it also extracts movement. When Kareem moves his head to the right, you will see this blue activity there; it represents regions where the contrast is increasing in the image, that's where it's going from dark to light. And you also see this yellow activity, which represents regions where contrast is decreasing; it's going from light to dark. And these four types of information — your optic nerve has about a million fibers in it, and 900,000 of those fibers send these four types of information. So we are really duplicating the kind of signals that you have on the optic nerve.What you notice here is that these snapshots taken from the output of the retina chip are very sparse, right? It doesn't light up green everywhere in the background, only on the edges, and then in the hair, and so on. And this is the same thing you see when people compress video to send: they want to make it very sparse, because that file is smaller. And this is what the retina is doing, and it's doing it just with the circuitry, and how this network of neurons that are interacting in there, which we've captured on the chip.But the point that I want to make — I'll show you up here. So this image here is going to look like these ones, but here I'll show you that we can reconstruct the image, so, you know, you can almost recognize Kareem in that top part there. And so, here you go. Yes, so that's the idea. When you stand still, you just see the light and dark contrasts. But when it's moving back and forth, the retina picks up these changes. And that's why, you know, when you're sitting here and something happens in your background, you merely move your eyes to it. There are these cells that detect change and you move your attention to it. So those are very important for catching somebody who's trying to sneak up on you.Let me just end by saying that this is what happens when you put Africa in a piano, OK. This is a steel drum here that has been modified, and that's what happens when you put Africa in a piano. And what I would like us to do is put Africa in the computer, and come up with a new kind of computer that will generate thought, imagination, be creative and things like that. Thank you. (Applause)Chris Anderson: Question for you, Kwabena. Do you put together in your mind the work you're doing, the future of Africa, this conference — what connections can we make, if any, between them?Kwabena Boahen: Yes, like I said at the beginning, I got my first computer when I was a teenager, growing up in Accra. And I had this gut reaction that this was the wrong way to do it. It was very brute force; it was very inelegant. I don't think that I would've had that reaction, if I'd grown up reading all this science fiction, hearing about RD2D2, whatever it was called, and just — you know, buying into this hype about computers. I was coming at it from a different perspective, where I was bringing that different perspective to bear on the problem. And I think a lot of people in Africa have this different perspective, and I think that's going to impact technology. And that's going to impact how it's going to evolve. And I think you're going to be able to see, use that infusion, to come up with new things, because you're coming from a different perspective. I think we can contribute. We can dream like everybody else.CA: Thanks Kwabena, that was really interesting. Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:16.958
I got my first computer when I was a teenager growing up in Accra,

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
and it was a really cool device.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:24.958
You could play games with it. You could program it in BASIC.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
And I was fascinated.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:32.958
So I went into the library to figure out how did this thing work.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:37.958
I read about how the CPU is constantly shuffling data back and forth

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:41.958
between the memory, the RAM and the ALU,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
the arithmetic and logic unit.

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And I thought to myself, this CPU really has to work like crazy

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:51.958
just to keep all this data moving through the system.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
But nobody was really worried about this.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
When computers were first introduced,

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
they were said to be a million times faster than neurons.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:04.958
People were really excited. They thought they would soon outstrip

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
the capacity of the brain.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
This is a quote, actually, from Alan Turing:

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:14.958
"In 30 years, it will be as easy to ask a computer a question

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
as to ask a person."

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:23.958
This was in 1946. And now, in 2007, it's still not true.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And so, the question is, why aren't we really seeing

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:31.958
this kind of power in computers that we see in the brain?

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:35.958
What people didn't realize, and I'm just beginning to realize right now,

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
is that we pay a huge price for the speed

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:41.958
that we claim is a big advantage of these computers.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
Let's take a look at some numbers.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:47.958
This is Blue Gene, the fastest computer in the world.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:52.958
It's got 120,000 processors; they can basically process

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
10 quadrillion bits of information per second.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:02:02.958
That's 10 to the sixteenth. And they consume one and a half megawatts of power.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
So that would be really great, if you could add that

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
to the production capacity in Tanzania.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
It would really boost the economy.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.958
Just to go back to the States,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
if you translate the amount of power or electricity

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
this computer uses to the amount of households in the States,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:22.958
you get 1,200 households in the U.S.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
That's how much power this computer uses.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
Now, let's compare this with the brain.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:32.958
This is a picture of, actually Rory Sayres' girlfriend's brain.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
Rory is a graduate student at Stanford.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:38.958
He studies the brain using MRI, and he claims that

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
this is the most beautiful brain that he has ever scanned.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
(Laughter)

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
So that's true love, right there.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Now, how much computation does the brain do?

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
I estimate 10 to the 16 bits per second,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:55.958
which is actually about very similar to what Blue Gene does.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
So that's the question. The question is, how much --

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
they are doing a similar amount of processing, similar amount of data --

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:05.958
the question is how much energy or electricity does the brain use?

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
And it's actually as much as your laptop computer:

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
it's just 10 watts.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
So what we are doing right now with computers

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
with the energy consumed by 1,200 houses,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:21.958
the brain is doing with the energy consumed by your laptop.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
So the question is, how is the brain able to achieve this kind of efficiency?

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
And let me just summarize. So the bottom line:

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
the brain processes information using 100,000 times less energy

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
than we do right now with this computer technology that we have.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
How is the brain able to do this?

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
Let's just take a look about how the brain works,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:43.958
and then I'll compare that with how computers work.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
So, this clip is from the PBS series, "The Secret Life of the Brain."

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
It shows you these cells that process information.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:51.958
They are called neurons.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:57.958
They send little pulses of electricity down their processes to each other,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
and where they contact each other, those little pulses

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
of electricity can jump from one neuron to the other.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
That process is called a synapse.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
You've got this huge network of cells interacting with each other --

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
about 100 million of them,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:12.958
sending about 10 quadrillion of these pulses around every second.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:18.958
And that's basically what's going on in your brain right now as you're watching this.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
How does that compare with the way computers work?

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
In the computer, you have all the data

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
going through the central processing unit,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
and any piece of data basically has to go through that bottleneck,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:31.958
whereas in the brain, what you have is these neurons,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:35.958
and the data just really flows through a network of connections

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
among the neurons. There's no bottleneck here.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:41.958
It's really a network in the literal sense of the word.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:45.958
The net is doing the work in the brain.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
If you just look at these two pictures,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
these kind of words pop into your mind.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:53.958
This is serial and it's rigid -- it's like cars on a freeway,

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
everything has to happen in lockstep --

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
whereas this is parallel and it's fluid.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
Information processing is very dynamic and adaptive.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:05.958
So I'm not the first to figure this out. This is a quote from Brian Eno:

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:09.958
"the problem with computers is that there is not enough Africa in them."

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:15.958
(Laughter)

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
Brian actually said this in 1995.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And nobody was listening then,

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
but now people are beginning to listen

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:28.958
because there's a pressing, technological problem that we face.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And I'll just take you through that a little bit in the next few slides.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.958
This is -- it's actually really this remarkable convergence

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:42.958
between the devices that we use to compute in computers,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:46.958
and the devices that our brains use to compute.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:50.958
The devices that computers use are what's called a transistor.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:54.958
This electrode here, called the gate, controls the flow of current

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
from the source to the drain -- these two electrodes.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
And that current, electrical current,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:05.958
is carried by electrons, just like in your house and so on.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:10.958
And what you have here is, when you actually turn on the gate,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
you get an increase in the amount of current, and you get a steady flow of current.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:18.958
And when you turn off the gate, there's no current flowing through the device.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:23.958
Your computer uses this presence of current to represent a one,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:27.958
and the absence of current to represent a zero.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:33.958
Now, what's happening is that as transistors are getting smaller and smaller and smaller,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
they no longer behave like this.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:40.958
In fact, they are starting to behave like the device that neurons use to compute,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
which is called an ion channel.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
And this is a little protein molecule.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:48.958
I mean, neurons have thousands of these.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
And it sits in the membrane of the cell and it's got a pore in it.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
And these are individual potassium ions

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
that are flowing through that pore.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
Now, this pore can open and close.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:04.958
But, when it's open, because these ions have to line up

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:09.958
and flow through, one at a time, you get a kind of sporadic, not steady --

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
it's a sporadic flow of current.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
And even when you close the pore -- which neurons can do,

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:20.958
they can open and close these pores to generate electrical activity --

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
even when it's closed, because these ions are so small,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
they can actually sneak through, a few can sneak through at a time.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
So, what you have is that when the pore is open,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
you get some current sometimes.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
These are your ones, but you've got a few zeros thrown in.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And when it's closed, you have a zero,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
but you have a few ones thrown in.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Now, this is starting to happen in transistors.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And the reason why that's happening is that, right now, in 2007 --

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.958
the technology that we are using -- a transistor is big enough

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:58.958
that several electrons can flow through the channel simultaneously, side by side.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
In fact, there's about 12 electrons can all be flowing this way.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
And that means that a transistor corresponds

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
to about 12 ion channels in parallel.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:12.958
Now, in a few years time, by 2015, we will shrink transistors so much.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
This is what Intel does to keep adding more cores onto the chip.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
Or your memory sticks that you have now can carry one gigabyte

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
of stuff on them -- before, it was 256.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
Transistors are getting smaller to allow this to happen,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
and technology has really benefitted from that.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:33.958
But what's happening now is that in 2015, the transistor is going to become so small,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
that it corresponds to only one electron at a time

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
can flow through that channel,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and that corresponds to a single ion channel.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
And you start having the same kind of traffic jams that you have in the ion channel.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
The current will turn on and off at random,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
even when it's supposed to be on.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And that means your computer is going to get

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:55.958
its ones and zeros mixed up, and that's going to crash your machine.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:59.958
So, we are at the stage where we

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
don't really know how to compute with these kinds of devices.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
And the only kind of thing -- the only thing we know right now

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
that can compute with these kinds of devices are the brain.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
OK, so a computer picks a specific item of data from memory,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
it sends it into the processor or the ALU,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and then it puts the result back into memory.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
That's the red path that's highlighted.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:23.958
The way brains work, I told you all, you have got all these neurons.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And the way they represent information is

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
they break up that data into little pieces

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
that are represented by pulses and different neurons.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
So you have all these pieces of data

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
distributed throughout the network.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
And then the way that you process that data to get a result

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:41.958
is that you translate this pattern of activity into a new pattern of activity,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
just by it flowing through the network.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
So you set up these connections

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
such that the input pattern just flows

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
and generates the output pattern.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
What you see here is that there's these redundant connections.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:59.958
So if this piece of data or this piece of the data gets clobbered,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:04.958
it doesn't show up over here, these two pieces can activate the missing part

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
with these redundant connections.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
So even when you go to these crappy devices

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
where sometimes you want a one and you get a zero, and it doesn't show up,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
there's redundancy in the network

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
that can actually recover the missing information.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
It makes the brain inherently robust.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
What you have here is a system where you store data locally.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:26.958
And it's brittle, because each of these steps has to be flawless,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
otherwise you lose that data, whereas in the brain, you have a system

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:33.958
that stores data in a distributed way, and it's robust.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:37.958
What I want to basically talk about is my dream,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
which is to build a computer that works like the brain.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:44.958
This is something that we've been working on for the last couple of years.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And I'm going to show you a system that we designed

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
to model the retina,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:55.958
which is a piece of brain that lines the inside of your eyeball.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:11:01.958
We didn't do this by actually writing code, like you do in a computer.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
In fact, the processing that happens

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
in that little piece of brain is very similar

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:07.958
to the kind of processing that computers

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
do when they stream video over the Internet.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:12.958
They want to compress the information --

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:16.958
they just want to send the changes, what's new in the image, and so on --

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
and that is how your eyeball

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
is able to squeeze all that information down to your optic nerve,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
to send to the rest of the brain.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
Instead of doing this in software, or doing those kinds of algorithms,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
we went and talked to neurobiologists

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
who have actually reverse engineered that piece of brain that's called the retina.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
And they figured out all the different cells,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
and they figured out the network, and we just took that network

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
and we used it as the blueprint for the design of a silicon chip.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:49.958
So now the neurons are represented by little nodes or circuits on the chip,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:54.958
and the connections among the neurons are represented, actually modeled by transistors.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
And these transistors are behaving essentially

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
just like ion channels behave in the brain.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.958
It will give you the same kind of robust architecture that I described.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
Here is actually what our artificial eye looks like.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:13.958
The retina chip that we designed sits behind this lens here.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
And the chip -- I'm going to show you a video

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
that the silicon retina put out of its output

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
when it was looking at Kareem Zaghloul,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
who's the student who designed this chip.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
Let me explain what you're going to see, OK,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
because it's putting out different kinds of information,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
it's not as straightforward as a camera.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
The retina chip extracts four different kinds of information.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
It extracts regions with dark contrast,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
which will show up on the video as red.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:43.958
And it extracts regions with white or light contrast,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
which will show up on the video as green.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
This is Kareem's dark eyes

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
and that's the white background that you see here.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And then it also extracts movement.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
When Kareem moves his head to the right,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
you will see this blue activity there;

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
it represents regions where the contrast is increasing in the image,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
that's where it's going from dark to light.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
And you also see this yellow activity,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
which represents regions where contrast is decreasing;

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
it's going from light to dark.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
And these four types of information --

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
your optic nerve has about a million fibers in it,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
and 900,000 of those fibers

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
send these four types of information.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
So we are really duplicating the kind of signals that you have on the optic nerve.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
What you notice here is that these snapshots

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
taken from the output of the retina chip are very sparse, right?

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
It doesn't light up green everywhere in the background,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
only on the edges, and then in the hair, and so on.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:39.958
And this is the same thing you see

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:43.958
when people compress video to send: they want to make it very sparse,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
because that file is smaller. And this is what the retina is doing,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:50.958
and it's doing it just with the circuitry, and how this network of neurons

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
that are interacting in there, which we've captured on the chip.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
But the point that I want to make -- I'll show you up here.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
So this image here is going to look like these ones,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
but here I'll show you that we can reconstruct the image,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:06.958
so, you know, you can almost recognize Kareem in that top part there.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
And so, here you go.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
Yes, so that's the idea.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
When you stand still, you just see the light and dark contrasts.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
But when it's moving back and forth,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
the retina picks up these changes.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And that's why, you know, when you're sitting here

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
and something happens in your background,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
you merely move your eyes to it.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
There are these cells that detect change

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
and you move your attention to it.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
So those are very important for catching somebody

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
who's trying to sneak up on you.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Let me just end by saying that this is what happens

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
when you put Africa in a piano, OK.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
This is a steel drum here that has been modified,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
and that's what happens when you put Africa in a piano.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
And what I would like us to do is put Africa in the computer,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
and come up with a new kind of computer

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
that will generate thought, imagination, be creative and things like that.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
Thank you.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
(Applause)

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
Kwabena Boahen: Yes, like I said at the beginning,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
I got my first computer when I was a teenager, growing up in Accra.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:27.958
And I had this gut reaction that this was the wrong way to do it.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:39.958

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:40.958

I was coming at it from a different perspective,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
