00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
the possibility of a nuclear attack,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
eliminating the threat altogether.

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.958
And I would like to make a case to you that

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.958
over the years since we first developed atomic weaponry,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
until this very moment,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
we've actually lived in a dangerous nuclear world

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
that's characterized by two phases,

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
which I'm going to go through with you right now.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:54.958
First of all, we started off the nuclear age in 1945.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
The United States had developed a couple of atomic weapons

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
through the Manhattan Project,

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
and the idea was very straightforward:

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
we would use the power of the atom

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
to end the atrocities and the horror

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
of this unending World War II

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
that we'd been involved in in Europe and in the Pacific.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
And in 1945,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
we were the only nuclear power.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
We had a few nuclear weapons,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
two of which we dropped on Japan, in Hiroshima,

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
a few days later in Nagasaki, in August 1945,

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
killing about 250,000 people between those two.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
And for a few years,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
we were the only nuclear power on Earth.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:33.958
But by 1949, the Soviet Union had decided

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.958
it was unacceptable to have us as the only nuclear power,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
and they began to match what the United States had developed.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
And from 1949 to 1985

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
was an extraordinary time

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
of a buildup of a nuclear arsenal

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
that no one could possibly have imagined

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
back in the 1940s.

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
So by 1985 -- each of those red bombs up here

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
is equivalent of a thousands warheads --

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
the world had

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
65,000 nuclear warheads,

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
and seven members of something

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
that came to be known as the "nuclear club."

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
And it was an extraordinary time,

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
and I am going to go through some of the mentality

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
that we -- that Americans and the rest of the world were experiencing.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
But I want to just point out to you that 95 percent

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
of the nuclear weapons at any particular time

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
since 1985 -- going forward, of course --

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
were part of the arsenals

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.958
of the United States and the Soviet Union.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
After 1985, and before the break up of the Soviet Union,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
we began to disarm

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
from a nuclear point of view.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
We began to counter-proliferate,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
and we dropped the number of nuclear warheads in the world

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
to about a total of 21,000.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:44.958
It's a very difficult number to deal with,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
because what we've done is

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
we've quote unquote "decommissioned" some of the warheads.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
They're still probably usable. They could be "re-commissioned,"

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
but the way they count things, which is very complicated,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
we think we have about a third

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
of the nuclear weapons we had before.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
But we also, in that period of time,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
added two more members to the nuclear club:

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
Pakistan and North Korea.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
So we stand today with a still fully armed nuclear arsenal

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
among many countries around the world,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
but a very different set of circumstances.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
So I'm going to talk about

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
a nuclear threat story in two chapters.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
Chapter one is 1949 to 1991,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
when the Soviet Union broke up,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
and what we were dealing with, at that point and through those years,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
was a superpowers' nuclear arms race.

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
It was characterized by

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
a nation-versus-nation,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
very fragile standoff.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
And basically,

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
we lived for all those years,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
and some might argue that we still do,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
in a situation of

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
being on the brink, literally,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:49.958
of an apocalyptic, planetary calamity.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
It's incredible that we actually lived through all that.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
We were totally dependent during those years

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
on this amazing acronym, which is MAD.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
It stands for mutually assured destruction.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
So it meant

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
if you attacked us, we would attack you

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
virtually simultaneously,

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
and the end result would be a destruction

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
of your country and mine.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
So the threat of my own destruction

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
kept me from launching

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
a nuclear attack on you. That's the way we lived.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
And the danger of that, of course, is that

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
a misreading of a radar screen

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
could actually cause a counter-launch,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
even though the first country had not actually launched anything.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
During this chapter one,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
there was a high level of public awareness

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
about the potential of nuclear catastrophe,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
and an indelible image was implanted

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
in our collective minds

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
that, in fact, a nuclear holocaust

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
would be absolutely globally destructive

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
and could, in some ways, mean the end of civilization as we know it.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
So this was chapter one.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
Now the odd thing is that even though

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
we knew that there would be

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
that kind of civilization obliteration,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
we engaged in America in a series --

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
and in fact, in the Soviet Union --

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
in a series of response planning.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
It was absolutely incredible.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
So premise one is we'd be destroying the world,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
and then premise two is, why don't we get prepared for it?

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
So what

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
we offered ourselves

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
was a collection of things. I'm just going to go skim through a few things,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
just to jog your memories.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
If you're born after 1950, this is just --

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
consider this entertainment, otherwise it's memory lane.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
This was Bert the Turtle. (Video)

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
This was basically an attempt

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
to teach our schoolchildren

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
that if we did get engaged

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
in a nuclear confrontation and atomic war,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
then we wanted our school children

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
to kind of basically duck and cover.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
That was the principle. You --

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
there would be a nuclear conflagration

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
about to hit us, and if you get under your desk,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
things would be OK.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
(Laughter)

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
I didn't do all that well

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
in psychiatry in medical school, but I was interested,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
and I think this was seriously delusional.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
(Laughter)

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
Secondly, we told people

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
to go down in their basements

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
and build a fallout shelter.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Maybe it would be a study when we weren't having an atomic war,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
or you could use it as a TV room, or, as many teenagers found out,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
a very, very safe place for a little privacy with your girlfriend.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And actually -- so there are multiple uses of the bomb shelters.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Or you could buy a prefabricated bomb shelter

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
that you could simply bury in the ground.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Now, the bomb shelters at that point --

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
let's say you bought a prefab one -- it would be a few hundred dollars,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
maybe up to 500, if you got a fancy one.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
Yet, what percentage of Americans

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
do you think ever had a bomb shelter in their house?

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
What percentage lived in a house with a bomb shelter?

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
Less than two percent. About 1.4 percent

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
of the population, as far as anyone knows,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
did anything,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
either making a space in their basement

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
or actually building a bomb shelter.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
Many buildings, public buildings, around the country --

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
this is New York City -- had these little civil defense signs,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
and the idea was that you would

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
run into one of these shelters and be safe

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
from the nuclear weaponry.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
And one of the greatest governmental delusions

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
of all time was something that happened

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
in the early days of

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
the Federal Emergency Management Agency, FEMA, as we now know,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and are well aware of their behaviors from Katrina.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
Here is their first big public

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
announcement.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
They would propose --

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
actually there were about six volumes written on this --

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
a crisis relocation plan

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
that was dependent upon

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
the United States having three to four days warning

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
that the Soviets were going to attack us.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
So the goal was to evacuate the target cities.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
We would move people out of the target cities

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
into the countryside.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And I'm telling you, I actually testified at the Senate

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
about the absolute ludicrous idea

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:57.958
that we would actually evacuate,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
and actually have three or four days' warning.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
It was just completely off the wall.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Turns out that they had another idea

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
behind it, even though this was --

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
they were telling the public it was to save us.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
The idea was that we would force the Soviets

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
to re-target their nuclear weapons -- very expensive --

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
and potentially double their arsenal,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
to not only take out the original site,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
but take out sites where people were going.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
This was what apparently, as it turns out, was behind all this.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
It was just really, really frightening.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
The main point here is we were dealing with

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
a complete disconnect from reality.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
The civil defense programs were disconnected

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
from the reality of what we'd see in all-out nuclear war.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
So organizations like Physicians for Social Responsibility,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
around 1979, started saying this a lot publicly.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
They would do a bombing run. They'd go to your city,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
and they'd say, "Here's a map of your city.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Here's what's going to happen if we get a nuclear hit."

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
So no possibility of medical response to,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
or meaningful preparedness for

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
all-out nuclear war.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
So we had to prevent nuclear war

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
if we expected to survive.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
This disconnect was never actually resolved.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
And what happened was --

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
when we get in to chapter two

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
of the nuclear threat era,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
which started back in 1945.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Chapter two starts in 1991.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
When the Soviet Union broke up,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
we effectively lost that adversary

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
as a potential attacker of the United States, for the most part.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
It's not completely gone. I'm going to come back to that.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
But from 1991

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
through the present time,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
emphasized by the attacks of 2001,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
the idea of an all-out nuclear war

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
has diminished and the idea of a single event,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
act of nuclear terrorism

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
is what we have instead.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
Although the scenario has changed

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
very considerably, the fact is

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
that we haven't changed our mental image

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
of what a nuclear war means.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
So I'm going to tell you what the implications of that are in just a second.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
So, what is a nuclear terror threat?

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And there's four key ingredients to describing that.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
First thing is that the global nuclear weapons,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
in the stockpiles that I showed you in those original maps,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
happen to be not uniformly secure.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
And it's particularly not secure

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
in the former Soviet Union, now in Russia.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
There are many, many sites where warheads are stored

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
and, in fact, lots of sites where fissionable materials,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
like highly enriched uranium and plutonium,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
are absolutely not safe.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
They're available to be bought, stolen, whatever.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
They're acquirable, let me put it that way.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
From 1993 through 2006,

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
the International Atomic Energy Agency

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
documented 175 cases of nuclear theft,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:38.958
18 of which involved highly enriched uranium or plutonium,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
the key ingredients to make a nuclear weapon.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
The global stockpile of highly enriched uranium

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
is about 1,300, at the low end,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
to about 2,100 metric tons.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
More than 100 megatons of this

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
is stored in particularly insecure

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
Russian facilities.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
How much of that do you think it would take

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
to actually build a 10-kiloton bomb?

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:06.958
Well, you need about 75 pounds of it.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
So, what I'd like to show you

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
is

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
what it would take to hold 75 pounds

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
of highly enriched uranium.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
This is not a product placement. It's just --

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
in fact, if I was Coca Cola, I'd be pretty distressed about this --

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
(Laughter)

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
-- but

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
basically, this is it.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
This is what you would need to steal or buy

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
out of that 100-metric-ton stockpile

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
that's relatively insecure

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
to create the type of bomb

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
that was used in Hiroshima.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Now you might want to look at plutonium

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
as another fissionable material that you might use in a bomb.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:49.958
That -- you'd need 10 to 13 pounds of plutonium.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
Now, plutonium, 10 to 13 pounds:

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
this. This is enough plutonium

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
to create a Nagasaki-size atomic weapon.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
Now this situation, already I --

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
you know, I don't really like thinking about this,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
although somehow I got myself a job

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
where I have to think about it. So

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
the point is that we're very, very insecure

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
in terms of developing this material.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
The second thing is, what about the know-how?

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And there's a lot of controversy about

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
whether terror organizations have the know-how

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
to actually make a nuclear weapon.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Well, there's a lot of know-how out there.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
There's an unbelievable amount of know-how out there.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
There's detailed information on how to assemble

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
a nuclear weapon from parts.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
There's books about how to build a nuclear bomb.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
There are plans for how to create a terror farm

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
where you could actually manufacture and develop

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
all the components and assemble it.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
All of this information is relatively available.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
If you have an undergraduate degree in physics,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
I would suggest --

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
although I don't, so maybe it's not even true --

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
but something close to that would allow you,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
with the information that's currently available,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
to actually build a nuclear weapon.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:07.958
The third element of the nuclear terror threat

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
is that, who would actually do such a thing?

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
Well, what we're seeing now is a level of terrorism

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
that involves individuals who are highly organized.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
They are very dedicated and committed.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
They are stateless.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
Somebody once said, Al Qaeda

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
does not have a return address,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
so if they attack us with a nuclear weapon,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
what's the response, and to whom is the response?

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
And they're retaliation-proof.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
Since there is no real retribution possible

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
that would make any difference,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
since there are people willing to actually give up their lives

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
in order to do a lot of damage to us,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
it becomes apparent

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
that the whole notion

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
of this mutually assured destruction would not work.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
Here is Sulaiman Abu Ghaith,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
and Sulaiman was a key lieutenant of Osama Bin Laden.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
He wrote many, many times statements to this effect:

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
"we have the right to kill four million Americans,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
two million of whom should be children."

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
And we don't have to go overseas

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
to find people willing to do harm, for whatever their reasons.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
McVeigh and Nichols, and the Oklahoma City attack

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
in the 1990s

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
was a good example of homegrown terrorists.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
What if they had gotten their hands on a nuclear weapon?

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
The fourth element

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
is that the high-value U.S. targets

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
are accessible, soft and plentiful.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
This would be a talk for another day, but the level of the preparedness

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
that the United States has achieved

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
since 9/11 of '01

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
is unbelievably inadequate.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
What you saw after Katrina

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
is a very good indicator

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
of how little prepared the United States is

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
for any kind of major attack.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
Seven million ship cargo containers

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
come into the United States every year.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Five to seven percent only are inspected --

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
five to seven percent.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
This is Alexander Lebed,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
who was a general that worked with Yeltsin,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
who talked about, and presented to Congress,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
this idea that the Russians had developed --

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
these suitcase bombs. They were very low yield --

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
0.1 to one kiloton,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
Hiroshima was around 13 kilotons --

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
but enough to do an unbelievable amount of damage.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
And Lebed came to the United States

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
and told us that many, many --

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
more than 80 of the suitcase bombs

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
were actually not accountable.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
And they look like this. They're basically very simple arrangements.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
You put the elements into a suitcase.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
It becomes very portable.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
The suitcase can be conveniently dropped

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
in your trunk of your car.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
You take it wherever you want to take it, and you can detonate it.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
You don't want to build a suitcase bomb,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
and you happen to get one of those insecure

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
nuclear warheads that exist.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
This is the size of

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
the "Little Boy" bomb that was dropped at Hiroshima.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
It was 9.8 feet long,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
weighed 8,800 pounds. You go down to

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
your local rent-a-truck

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
and for 50 bucks or so,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
you rent a truck that's got the right capacity,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
and you take your bomb,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
you put it in the truck and you're ready to go.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
It could happen. But what it would mean and who would survive?

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
You can't get an exact number for that kind of probability,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
but what I'm trying to say is that

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
we have all the elements of that happening.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
Anybody who dismisses the thought

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
of a nuclear weapon

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
being used by a terrorist is kidding themselves.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
I think there's a lot of people in the intelligence community --

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
a lot of people who deal with this work in general

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
think it's almost inevitable, unless we do certain things

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
to really try to defuse the risk,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
like better interdiction, better prevention,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
better fixing, you know, better screening

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
of cargo containers that are coming into the country and so forth.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
There's a lot that can be done to make us a lot safer.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
At this particular moment,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
we actually could end up

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
seeing a nuclear detonation in one of our cities.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
I don't think we would see an all-out nuclear war

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
any time soon, although even that is not completely off the table.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
There's still enough nuclear weapons

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
in the arsenals of the superpowers

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
to destroy the Earth many, many times over.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
There are flash points in India and Pakistan,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
in the Middle East, in North Korea,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
other places where the use of nuclear weapons,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
while initially locally,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
could very rapidly

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
go into a situation

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
where we'd be facing all-out nuclear war.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
It's very unsettling.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
Here we go. OK.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
I'm back in my truck, and we drove over the Brooklyn Bridge.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
We're coming down,

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
and we bring that truck

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
that you just saw

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:28.958
somewhere in here, in the Financial District.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
This is a 10-kiloton bomb,

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:44.958
slightly smaller than was used

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
in Hiroshima. And I want to just conclude this

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
by just giving you some information. I think --

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
"news you could use" kind of concept here.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
So, first of all, this would be horrific

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
beyond anything we can possibly imagine.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
This is the ultimate.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:00.958
And if you're in the half-mile radius

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:02.958
of where this bomb went off,

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
you have a 90 percent chance of not making it.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
If you're right where the bomb went off,

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
you will be vaporized. And that's --

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
I'm just telling you, this is not good.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
(Laughter)

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
You assume that.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
Two-mile radius, you have a 50 percent chance

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
of being killed,

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:21.958
and up to about eight miles away --

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:23.958
now I'm talking about killed instantly --

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.958
somewhere between a 10 and 20 percent

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
chance of getting killed.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
The thing about this is that

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:33.958
the experience of the nuclear detonation is --

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
first of all, tens of millions of degrees Fahrenheit

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:38.958
at the core here, where it goes off,

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:40.958
and an extraordinary amount of energy

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.958
in the form of heat, acute radiation

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
and blast effects.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
An enormous hurricane-like wind,

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
and destruction of buildings almost totally,

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:52.958
within this yellow circle here.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:54.958
And what I'm going to focus on, as I come to conclusion here,

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
is that, what happens to you

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
if you're in here?

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
Well, if we're talking about the old days

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
of an all-out nuclear attack,

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:04.958
you, up here,

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:07.958
are as dead as the people here. So it was a moot point.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
My point now, though, is that there is a lot

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:11.958
that we could do for you who are in here,

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:13.958
if you've survived the initial blast.

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:15.958
You have, when the blast goes off --

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:17.958
and by the way, if it ever comes up, don't look at it.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:19.958
(Laughter)

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:21.958
If you look at it, you're going to be blind,

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
either temporarily or permanently.

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:25.958
So if there's any way that you can avoid,

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
like, avert your eyes, that would be a good thing.

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
If you find yourself alive, but

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.958
you're in the vicinity of a nuclear weapon,

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:35.958
you have -- that's gone off --

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:37.958
you have 10 to 20 minutes, depending on the size

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.958
and exactly where it went off,

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
to get out of the way before

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.958
a lethal amount of radiation

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:46.958
comes straight down from the mushroom cloud that goes up.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:48.958
In that 10 to 15 minutes, all you have to do --

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:50.958
and I mean this seriously --

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:52.958
is go about a mile

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:54.958
away from the blast.

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:56.958
And what happens is -- this is --

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:58.958
I'm going to show you now some fallout plumes. Within 20 minutes,

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:00.958
it comes straight down. Within 24 hours,

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:03.958
lethal radiation is going out with prevailing winds,

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:05.958
and it's mostly in this particular direction --

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:07.958
it's going northeast.

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:10.958
And if you're in this vicinity, you've got to get away.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:12.958
So you're feeling the wind --

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:14.958
and there's tremendous wind now

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:16.958
that you're going to be feeling -- and you want to go

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:18.958
perpendicular to the wind

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:20.958
[not upwind or downwind].

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:23.958
if you are in fact able to see where the blast was in front of you.

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:25.958
You've got to get out of there.

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:27.958
If you don't get out of there, you're going to be exposed

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:29.958
to lethal radiation in very short order.

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:31.958
If you can't get out of there,

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:34.958
we want you to go into a shelter and stay there.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:37.958
Now, in a shelter in an urban area means

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:40.958
you have to be either in a basement as deep as possible,

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:43.958
or you have to be on a floor -- on a high floor --

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:46.958
if it's a ground burst explosion, which it would be,

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:48.958
higher than the ninth floor. So you have to be tenth floor or higher,

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:50.958
or in the basement.

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:54.958
But basically, you've got to get out of town as quickly as possible.

00:20:54.958 --> 00:20:56.958
And if you do that,

00:20:56.958 --> 00:21:00.958
you actually can survive a nuclear blast.

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:02.958
Over the next few days to a week,

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:04.958
there will be a radiation cloud,

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:06.958
again, going with the wind, and settling down

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:08.958
for another 15 or 20 miles out --

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:10.958
in this case, over Long Island.

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:13.958
And if you're in the direct fallout zone here,

00:21:13.958 --> 00:21:15.958
you really have to either be sheltered or you have to get out of there,

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
and that's clear. But if you are sheltered,

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:20.958
you can actually survive.

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:22.958
The difference between knowing information

00:21:22.958 --> 00:21:24.958
of what you're going to do personally,

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:26.958
and not knowing information, can save your life,

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:28.958
and it could mean the difference between

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:30.958
150,000 to 200,000 fatalities

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:33.958
from something like this

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
and half a million to 700,000 fatalities.

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:39.958
So, response planning in the twenty-first century

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:41.958
is both possible and is essential.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:45.958
But in 2008, there isn't one single American city

00:21:45.958 --> 00:21:47.958
that has done effective plans

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:50.958
to deal with a nuclear detonation disaster.

00:21:50.958 --> 00:21:52.958
Part of the problem is that

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:54.958
the emergency planners themselves, personally,

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:56.958
are overwhelmed psychologically by the thought

00:21:56.958 --> 00:21:58.958
of nuclear catastrophe.

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:00.958
They are paralyzed.

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:02.958
You say "nuclear" to them, and they're thinking,

00:22:02.958 --> 00:22:05.958
"Oh my God, we're all gone. What's the point? It's futile."

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:07.958
And we're trying to tell them, "It's not futile.

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:09.958
We can change the survival rates

00:22:09.958 --> 00:22:12.958
by doing some commonsensical things."

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:15.958
So the goal here is to minimize fatalities.

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:17.958
And I just want to leave you with the personal points

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:19.958
that I think you might be interested in.

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:21.958
The key to surviving a nuclear blast

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:23.958
is getting out,

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:26.958
and not going into harm's way.

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:28.958
That's basically all we're going to be talking about here.

00:22:28.958 --> 00:22:31.958
And the farther you are away in distance,

00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:33.958
the longer it is in time

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:35.958
from the initial blast;

00:22:35.958 --> 00:22:37.958
and the more separation between you

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:39.958
and the outside atmosphere, the better.

00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:42.958
So separation -- hopefully with dirt or concrete,

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:44.958
or being in a basement --

00:22:44.958 --> 00:22:46.958
distance and time is what will save you.

00:22:46.958 --> 00:22:48.958
So here's what you do. First of all,

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:50.958
as I said, don't stare at the light flash,

00:22:50.958 --> 00:22:52.958
if you can. I don't know you could possibly resist doing that.

00:22:52.958 --> 00:22:54.958
But let's assume, theoretically, you want to do that.

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:56.958
You want to keep your mouth open, so your eardrums

00:22:56.958 --> 00:22:59.958
don't burst from the pressures.

00:22:59.958 --> 00:23:02.958
If you're very close to what happened, you actually do have to duck and cover,

00:23:02.958 --> 00:23:04.958
like Bert told you, Bert the Turtle.

00:23:04.958 --> 00:23:07.958
And you want to get under something so that you're not injured

00:23:07.958 --> 00:23:09.958
or killed by objects, if that's at all possible.

00:23:09.958 --> 00:23:11.958
You want to get away from the initial fallout mushroom cloud,

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:13.958
I said, in just a few minutes.

00:23:13.958 --> 00:23:16.958
And shelter and place. You want to move [only]

00:23:16.958 --> 00:23:18.958
crosswind for 1.2 miles.

00:23:18.958 --> 00:23:21.958
You know, if you're out there and you see buildings horribly destroyed

00:23:21.958 --> 00:23:23.958
and down in that direction,

00:23:23.958 --> 00:23:25.958
less destroyed here,

00:23:25.958 --> 00:23:27.958
then you know that it was over there, the blast, and you're going this way,

00:23:27.958 --> 00:23:31.958
as long as you're going crosswise to the wind.

00:23:31.958 --> 00:23:33.958
Once you're out and evacuating,

00:23:33.958 --> 00:23:34.958
you want to keep as much of your skin,

00:23:35.958 --> 00:23:37.958
your mouth and nose covered, as long as that covering

00:23:37.958 --> 00:23:40.958
doesn't impede you moving and getting out of there.

00:23:40.958 --> 00:23:43.958
And finally, you want to get decontaminated as soon as possible.

00:23:43.958 --> 00:23:45.958
And if you're wearing clothing, you've taken off your clothing,

00:23:45.958 --> 00:23:47.958
you're going to get showered down some place

00:23:47.958 --> 00:23:49.958
and remove the radiation that would be --

00:23:49.958 --> 00:23:52.958
the radioactive material that might be on you.

00:23:52.958 --> 00:23:56.958
And then you want to stay in shelter for 48 to 72 hours minimum,

00:23:56.958 --> 00:23:58.958
but you're going to wait hopefully -- you'll have your little wind-up,

00:23:58.958 --> 00:24:00.958
battery-less radio,

00:24:00.958 --> 00:24:02.958
and you'll be waiting for people to tell you

00:24:02.958 --> 00:24:04.958
when it's safe to go outside. That's what you need to do.

00:24:04.958 --> 00:24:06.958
In conclusion,

00:24:06.958 --> 00:24:08.958
nuclear war is less likely than before,

00:24:08.958 --> 00:24:11.958
but by no means out of the question, and it's not survivable.

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:14.958
Nuclear terrorism is possible -- it may be probable --

00:24:14.958 --> 00:24:16.958
but is survivable.

00:24:16.958 --> 00:24:18.958
And this is Jack Geiger, who's one of the heroes

00:24:18.958 --> 00:24:21.958
of the U.S. public health community.

00:24:21.958 --> 00:24:23.958
And Jack said the only way to deal

with nuclear anything,

title: A free digital library
transcript: We really need to put the best we have to offer within reach of our children. If we don't do that, we're going to get the generation we deserve. They're going to learn from whatever it is they have around them.And we, as now the elite, parents, librarians, professionals, whatever it is, a bunch of our activities are, in fact, in trying to get the best we have to offer within reach of those around us, or as broadly as we can. I'm going to start and end this talk with a couple things that are carved in stone. One is what's on the Boston Public Library. Carved above their door is, "Free to All." It's kind of an inspiring statement, and I'll go back at the end of this. I'm a librarian, and what I'm trying to do is bring all of the works of knowledge to as many people as want to read it. And the idea of using technology is perfect for us. I think we have the opportunity to one-up the Greeks. It's not easy to one-up the Greeks. But with the industriousness of the Egyptians, they were able to build the Library of Alexandria — the idea of a copy of every book of all the peoples of the world. The problem was you actually had to go to Alexandria to go to it. On the other hand, if you did, then great things happened. I think we can one-up the Greeks and achieve something. And I'm going to try to argue only one point today: that universal access to all knowledge is within our grasp. So if I'm successful, then you'll actually come away thinking, yeah, we could actually achieve the great vision of everything ever published, everything that was ever meant for distribution, available to anybody in the world that's ever wanted to have access to it.Yes, there's issues about how money should be distributed, and that's still being refigured out. But I'd say there's plenty of money, and there's plenty of demand, so we can actually achieve that. But I'm going to go over the technological, social and sort of where are we as a whole, trying to get to that particular vision. And the way I'm going to try to do this is do it like the Amazon.com website, the books, music, video and just go step — media type by media type, just go and say, all right, how're we doing on this?So if we start with books, you know, sort of where are we? Well, first you have to, as an engineer, scope the problem. How big is it? If you wanted to put all of the published works online so that anybody could have it available, well, how big a problem is it? Well, we don't really know, but the largest print library in the world is the Library of Congress. It's 26 million volumes, 26 million volumes. It is, by far and away, the largest print library in the world. And a book, if you had a book, is about a megabyte, so — you know, if you had it in Microsoft Word. So a megabyte, 26 million megabytes is 26 terabytes — it goes mega-, giga-, tera-. 26 terabytes. 26 terabytes fits in a computer system that's about this big, on spinning Linux drives, and it costs about 60,000 dollars. So for the cost of a house — or around here, a garage — you can put, you can have spinning all of the words in the Library of Congress. That's pretty neat.Then the question is, what do you get? You know, is it worth trying to get there? Do you actually want it online? Some of the first things that people do is they make book readers that allow you to search inside the books, and that's kind of fun. And you can download these things, and look around them in new and different ways. And you can get at them remotely, if you happen to have a laptop. There's starting to be some of these sort of page turn-y interfaces that look a whole lot like books in certain ways, and you can search them, make little tabs, and it's kind of cute — still very book-like — on your laptop. But I don't know, reading things on a laptop — whenever I pull up my laptop, it always feels like work. I think that's one of the reasons why the Kindle is so great. I don't have to feel like I'm at work to read a Kindle. It's starting to be a little bit more specified. But I have to say that there's older technologies that I tend to like. I like the physical book. And I think we can go and use our technology to go and digitize things, put them on the Net, and then download, print them and bind them, and end up with books again.And we sort of said, well, how hard is this? And it turns out to not be very hard. We actually went off to make a bookmobile. And a bookmobile — the size of a van with a satellite dish, a printer, binder and cutter, and kids make their own books. It costs about three dollars to download, print and bind a normal, old book. And they actually come out kind of nice looking. You can actually get really good-looking books for on the order of one penny per page, sort of the parts cost for doing this.So the idea of — this technology actually may end up putting books back in people's hands again. There are some other bookmobiles running around. This is Eric Eldred making books at Walden Pond — Thoreau's works. This is just before he got kicked out by the Parks Services, for competing with the bookstore there. In India, they've got another couple bookmobiles running around. And this is the opening day at the Library of Alexandria, the new Library of Alexandria, in Egypt. It was quite popularly attended. And kids starting to make their own books, and a happy kid with the first book that he's ever owned. So the idea of being able to use this technology to end up with paper where I can handle sort of sounds a little retro, but I think it still has its place. And being from the Silicon Valley, sort of utopian sort of world, we thought, if we can make this technology work in rural Uganda, we might have something. So we actually got some funding from the World Bank to try it out. And we found in about 30 days we could go and take a couple folks from Silicon Valley, fly them to Uganda, buy a car, set up the first Internet connection at the National Library of Uganda, figure out what they wanted, and get a program going making books in rural Uganda. And it actually — so technologically, it works.What we found out of this is we didn't have the right books. So the books were in the library. We could get it to people, if they're digitized, but we didn't know how to quite get them digitized. Everybody thought the answer is, send things to India and China. And so we've tried that, and I'll go over that in a moment. There are some newer technologies for delivering that have happened that are actually quite exciting as well. One is a print-on-demand machine that looks like a Rube Goldberg machine. We have one of these things now. It's completely cool. It's all conveyor belt, and it makes a book. And it's called the "Espresso Book Machine," and in about 10 minutes, you can press a button and make a book.Something else I'm quite excited about in this particular domain, beyond these sort of kiosk-y things where you can get books on demand, is some of these new little screens that are coming out. And one of my favorites in this is the $100 laptop. And I don't mean to steal any thunder here, but we've gone and used one of these things to be an e-book reader. So here's one of the beta units and you can — it actually turns out to be a really good-looking e-book reader. And we have a quick hack that we did to try to put one of our books on it, and it turns out that 200 dots per inch means that you can put scanned books on them that look really good. At 200 dots per inch, it's kind of the equivalent of a 300 dot print laser printer. We're in good enough shape. You actually can go and read scanned books quite easily.So the idea of electronic books is starting to come about. But how do you go about doing all this scanning? So we thought, okay, well, let's try out this send books to India thing. And there was a project with, funded by the National Science Foundation — sent a bunch of scanners, and the American libraries were supposed to send books. Well, they didn't. They didn't want to send their books. So we bought 100,000 books and sent them to India. And then we learned why you don't want to send books to India. The lesson we learned out of this is, scan your own books. If you really care about books, you're going to scan them better, especially if they're valuable books. If they're new books and you can just, you know, butcher them, because you could just buy another one, that's not such a big deal in terms of doing high-quality scanning. But do things that you love. But the Indians have been scanning a lot of their own books — about 300,000 now — doing very well. The Chinese did over a million, and the Egyptians are about 30,000.But we sent — thought, OK, if we're going to need to do this, let's do it in-library. How do we go and do this, and how do we get it down so that it's a cost point that we could afford? And we sort of picked the price point of 10 cents a page. If it's basically the cost of xeroxing to basically digitize, OCR, package it up, make it so that you could download, print and bind it — the whole shebang — we would have achieved something. So we started out trying to figure out. How do we get to 10 cents? And we tried these robot things, and they worked pretty well — sort of these auto-page-turning things. If we can have Mars Rovers, you'd think you could turn pages. But it actually turns out to be pretty hard to turn pages, and the volume isn't there. So anyway — so we ended up making our own book scanner, and with two digital, high-grade, professional digital cameras, controlled museum lighting, so even if it's a black and white book, you can go and get the proper intonation. So you basically do a beautiful, respectful job. This is not a fax, this is — the idea is to do a beautiful job as you're going through these libraries. And we've been able to achieve 10 cents a page if we run things in volume. This is what it looks like at the University of Toronto. And actually, it turns out to, you know, pay a living wage. People seem to love it. Yes, it's a little boring, but some people kind of get into the Zen of it. (Laughter) And especially if it's kind of interesting books that you care about, in languages that you can read. We actually have been able to do a pretty good job of this, at getting 10 cents a page. So 10 cents a page, 300 pages in your average book, 30 dollars a book. The Library of Congress, if you did the whole darn thing — 26 million books — is about 750 million dollars, right? But a million books, I think, actually would be a pretty good start, and that would cost 30 million dollars. That's not that big a bill.And what we've been able to do is get into libraries. We've now got eight of these scanning centers in three countries, and libraries are up for having their books scanned. The Getty here is moving their books to the UCLA, which is where we have one these scanning centers, and scanning their out-of-copyright books, which is fabulous. So we're starting to get the institutional responsibility. The thing we're missing is the 10 cents. If we can get the 10 cents, all the rest of it flows. We've scanned about 200,000 books. Now we're scanning about 15,000 books a month, and it's starting to gear up another factor of two from there.So all in all, that's going very well. And we're starting to move out of the just out-of-copyright into the out-of-print world. So I think of — we're kind of going from the out-of-copyright, library stuff, and Amazon.com is coming from the in-print world. And I think we'll meet in the middle some place, and have the classic thing that you have, which is a publishing system and a library system working in parallel. And so we're starting up a program to do out-of-print works, but loaning them. Exactly what loaning means, I'm not quite sure. But anyway, loaning out-of-print works from the Boston Public Library, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute and a few other libraries that are starting to participate in this program, to try out this model of where does a library stop and where does the bookstore take over. So all in all, it's possible to do this in large scale. We're also going back over microfilm and getting that online. So, we can do 10 cents a page, we're going 15,000 books a month and we've got about 250,000 books online, counting all the other projects that are starting to add in. So what I wanted to argue is, books are within our grasp. The idea of taking on the whole ball of wax is not that big a deal. Yes, it costs tens of millions, low hundreds of millions, but one time shot and we've got basically the history of printed literature online. And then, there's business model issues about how to try to effectively market it and get it to people. But it is within our grasp, technologically and law-wise, at least for the out of print and out of copyright, we suggest, to be able to get the whole darn thing online.Now let's go for audio, and I'm going to go through these. So how much is there? Well, as best we can tell, there are about two to three million disks having been published — so 78s, long-playing records and CDs — or at least that's the largest archives of published materials we've been able to sort of point at. It costs about 10 dollars a piece to go and take a disk and put it online, if you're doing things in volume. But we've found that the rights issues are really quite thorny. This is a fairly heavily litigated area, so we've found that there are niches in the music world that aren't served terribly well by the classic commercial publishing system. And we've been starting to make these available by going and offering shelf space on the Net. In the United States, it doesn't cost you to give something away. Right? If you give something to a charity or to the public, you get a pat on the back and a tax donation — except on the Net, where you can go broke. If you put up a video of your garage band, and it starts getting heavily accessed, you can lose your guitars or your house.This doesn't make any sense. So we've offered unlimited storage, unlimited bandwidth, forever, for free, to anybody that has something to share that belongs in a library. And we've been getting a lot of takers. One is the rock 'n' rollers. The rock 'n' rollers had a tradition of sharing, as long as nobody made any money. You could — concert recordings, it's not the commercial recordings, but concert recordings, started by the Grateful Dead. And we get about two or three bands a day signing up. They give permission, and we get about 40 or 50 concerts a day. We have about 40,000 concerts, everything the Grateful Dead ever did, up on the Net, so that people can see it and listen to this material. So audio is possible to put up, but the rights issues are really pretty thorny. We've got a lot of collections now — a couple hundred thousand items — and it's growing over time.Moving images: if you think of theatrical releases, there are not that many of them. As best we can tell, there are about 150,000 to 200,000 movies ever that are really meant for a large-scale theatrical distribution. It's just not that many. But half of those were Indian. But anyway, it's doable, but we've only found about a thousand of these things that — to be out of copyright. So we've digitized those and made those available. But we've found that there's lots of other types of movies that haven't really seen the light of day — archival films. We've found, also, a lot of political films, a lot of amateur films, all sorts of things that are basically needing a home, a permanent home. So we've been starting to make these available and it's grown to be very popular. We're not quite a YouTube. We tended towards longer-term things and also things that people can reuse and make into new movies, which has just been great fun.Television comes quite a bit larger. We started recording 20 channels of television 24 hours a day. It's sort of the biggest TiVo box you've ever seen. It's about a petabyte, so far, of worldwide television — Russian, Chinese, Japanese, Iraqi, Al Jazeera, BBC, CNN, ABC, CBS, NBC — 24 hours a day. We only put one week up, which is mostly for cost reasons, which is the 9/11, sort of from 9/11/2001. For one week, what did the world see? CNN was saying that Palestinians were dancing in the streets. Were they? Let's look at the Palestinian television and find out. How can we have critical thinking without being able to quote and being able to compare what happened in the past? And television is dreadfully unrecorded and unquotable, except by Jon Stewart, who does a fabulous job. So anyway, television is, I would suggest, within our grasp. So 15 dollars per video hour, and also about 100 dollars to 150 dollars per celluloid hour, we're able to go and get materials online very inexpensively and have them up on the Net. And we've got, now, a lot of these materials. So we've got about 100,000 pieces up there. So books, music, video, software. There's only 50,000 titles of it. Mostly the issues there are legal issues and breaking copy protections. But we've worked through some of those, but we've still got real problems in Washington.Well, we're best known as the World Wide Web. We've been archiving the World Wide Web since 1996. We take a snapshot of every website and all of the pages on it, every two months. And actually, it's really been pioneered by Alexa Internet, which donates this collection to the Internet Archive. And it's been growing along for the last 11 years, and it's a fantastic resource. And we've made a Wayback Machine that you can then go and see old websites kind of the way they were. If you go and search on something — this is Google.com, the different versions of it that we have, this is what it looks like when it was an alpha release, and this is what it looked like at Stanford. So anyway, you've got basically an idea of where things came from. Mostly, people want to see their old stuff out of this. If there's one thing that we want to learn from the Library of Alexandria version one, which is probably best known for burning, is, don't just have one copy. So we've started to — we've made another copy of all of this and we actually put it back in the Library of Alexandria. So this is a picture of the Internet Archive at the Library of Alexandria. And we now have also another copy building up in Amsterdam. So, we should put it in the San Andreas Fault Line in San Francisco, flood zone in Amsterdam and in the Middle East. Right, so anyway ... so we're hedging our bets here. If we go and put it in a couple more places, I think we'll be in good shape.There's a political and social question out of this. Is all of this, as we go digital, is it going to be public or private? There's some large companies that have seen this vision, that are doing large-scale digitization, but they're locking up the public domain. The question is, is that the world that we really want to live in? What's the role of the public versus the private as things go forward? How do we go and have a world where we both have libraries and publishing in the future, just as we basically benefited as we were growing up? So universal access to all knowledge — I think it can be one of the greatest achievements of humankind, like the man on the moon, or the Gutenberg Bible, or the Library of Alexandria. It could be something that we're remembered for, for millennia, for having achieved. And as I said before, I'll end with something that's carved above the door of the Carnegie Library. Carnegie — one of the great capitalists of this country — carved above his legacy, "Free to the People." Thank you very much.
