So the idea of -- this technology actually may end up

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
putting books back in people's hands again.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
There are some other bookmobiles running around.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:05.958
This is Eric Eldred making books at Walden Pond -- Thoreau's works.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
This is just before he got kicked out by the Parks Services,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
for competing with the bookstore there.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
In India, they've got another couple bookmobiles running around.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And this is the opening day at the Library of Alexandria,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:21.958
the new Library of Alexandria, in Egypt.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
It was quite popularly attended.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
And kids starting to make their own books,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and a happy kid with the first book that he's ever owned.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
So the idea of being able to use this technology

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
to end up with paper where I can handle sort of sounds a little retro,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
but I think it still has its place.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
And being from the Silicon Valley, sort of utopian

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
sort of world,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
we thought, if we can make this technology work in rural Uganda,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
we might have something.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
So we actually got some funding from the World Bank to try it out.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:56.958
And we found in about 30 days we could go and take a couple folks from Silicon Valley,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:02.958
fly them to Uganda, buy a car, set up the first Internet connection

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
at the National Library of Uganda, figure out what they wanted,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
and get a program going making books in rural Uganda.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And it actually -- so technologically, it works.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
What we found out of this is we didn't have the right books.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
So the books were in the library. We could get it to people, if they're digitized,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
but we didn't know how to quite get them digitized.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Everybody thought the answer is, send things to India and China.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
And so we've tried that, and I'll go over that in a moment.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
There are some newer technologies for delivering

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
that have happened that are actually quite exciting as well.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
One is a print-on-demand machine that looks like a Rube Goldberg machine.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
We have one of these things now. It's completely cool.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:44.958
It's all conveyor belt, and it makes a book.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And it's called the "Espresso Book Machine,"

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:50.958
and in about 10 minutes, you can press a button and make a book.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
Something else I'm quite excited about in this particular domain,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
beyond these sort of kiosk-y things where you can get books on demand,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
is some of these new little screens that are coming out.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
And one of my favorites in this is the $100 laptop.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And I don't mean to steal any thunder here,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
but we've gone and used one of these things to be an e-book reader.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:25.958
So here's one of the beta units and you can --

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:33.958
it actually turns out to be a really good-looking e-book reader.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
And we have a quick hack that we did to try to put one of our books on it,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
and it turns out that 200 dots per inch

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
means that you can put scanned books on them that look really good.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:47.958
At 200 dots per inch, it's kind of the equivalent of a 300 dot print laser printer.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
We're in good enough shape.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
You actually can go and read scanned books quite easily.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958
So the idea of electronic books is starting to come about.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
But how do you go about doing all this scanning?

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
So we thought, okay, well, let's try out this send books to India thing.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:06.958
And there was a project with, funded by the National Science Foundation --

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:10.958
sent a bunch of scanners, and the American libraries were supposed to send books.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
Well, they didn't. They didn't want to send their books.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
So we bought 100,000 books and sent them to India.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
And then we learned why you don't want to send books to India.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:22.958
The lesson we learned out of this is, scan your own books.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:26.958
If you really care about books, you're going to scan them better,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
especially if they're valuable books.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
If they're new books and you can just, you know, butcher them,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
because you could just buy another one,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
that's not such a big deal in terms of doing high-quality scanning.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
But do things that you love.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
But the Indians have been scanning a lot of their own books --

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
about 300,000 now -- doing very well.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:49.958
The Chinese did over a million, and the Egyptians are about 30,000.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:55.958
But we sent -- thought, OK, if we're going to need to do this, let's do it in-library.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
How do we go and do this, and how do we get it down

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
so that it's a cost point that we could afford?

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
And we sort of picked the price point of 10 cents a page.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:08.958
If it's basically the cost of xeroxing to basically digitize, OCR, package it up,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
make it so that you could download, print and bind it -- the whole shebang --

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
we would have achieved something.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
So we started out trying to figure out. How do we get to 10 cents?

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
And we tried these robot things, and they worked pretty well --

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
sort of these auto-page-turning things.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
If we can have Mars Rovers, you'd think you could turn pages.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:28.958
But it actually turns out to be pretty hard to turn pages, and the volume isn't there.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:34.958
So anyway -- so we ended up making our own book scanner,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
and with two digital, high-grade, professional digital cameras,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
controlled museum lighting, so even if it's a black and white book,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:45.958
you can go and get the proper intonation.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
So you basically do a beautiful, respectful job.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
This is not a fax, this is -- the idea is to do a beautiful job

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
as you're going through these libraries.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:59.958
And we've been able to achieve 10 cents a page if we run things in volume.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
This is what it looks like at the University of Toronto.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And actually, it turns out to, you know, pay a living wage.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
People seem to love it.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Yes, it's a little boring, but some people kind of get into the Zen of it.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
(Laughter)

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
And especially if it's kind of interesting books that you care about,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
in languages that you can read.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:24.958
We actually have been able to do a pretty good job of this, at getting 10 cents a page.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.958
So 10 cents a page, 300 pages in your average book, 30 dollars a book.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
The Library of Congress, if you did the whole darn thing --

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
26 million books -- is about 750 million dollars, right?

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
But a million books, I think, actually would be a pretty good start,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and that would cost 30 million dollars. That's not that big a bill.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
And what we've been able to do is get into libraries.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:50.958
We've now got eight of these scanning centers in three countries,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and libraries are up for having their books scanned.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
The Getty here is moving their books to the UCLA,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
which is where we have one these scanning centers,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
and scanning their out-of-copyright books, which is fabulous.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
So we're starting to get the institutional responsibility.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
The thing we're missing is the 10 cents.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
If we can get the 10 cents, all the rest of it flows.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
We've scanned about 200,000 books.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
Now we're scanning about 15,000 books a month,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
and it's starting to gear up another factor of two from there.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
So all in all, that's going very well.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And we're starting to move out of the just out-of-copyright

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
into the out-of-print world.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
So I think of -- we're kind of going from the out-of-copyright, library stuff,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:39.958
and Amazon.com is coming from the in-print world.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
And I think we'll meet in the middle some place,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
and have the classic thing that you have,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:47.958
which is a publishing system and a library system working in parallel.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And so we're starting up a program to do out-of-print works, but loaning them.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Exactly what loaning means, I'm not quite sure.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:00.958
But anyway, loaning out-of-print works from the Boston Public Library,

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:04.958
the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute and a few other libraries

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
that are starting to participate in this program,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
to try out this model of where does a library stop

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
and where does the bookstore take over.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:16.958
So all in all, it's possible to do this in large scale.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:21.958
We're also going back over microfilm and getting that online.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
So, we can do 10 cents a page, we're going 15,000 books a month

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
and we've got about 250,000 books online,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
counting all the other projects that are starting to add in.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:33.958
So what I wanted to argue is, books are within our grasp.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:39.958
The idea of taking on the whole ball of wax is not that big a deal.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:43.958
Yes, it costs tens of millions, low hundreds of millions,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:50.958
but one time shot and we've got basically the history of printed literature online.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And then, there's business model issues

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
about how to try to effectively market it and get it to people.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:00.958
But it is within our grasp, technologically and law-wise,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
at least for the out of print and out of copyright,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
we suggest, to be able to get the whole darn thing online.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
Now let's go for audio, and I'm going to go through these.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
So how much is there?

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
Well, as best we can tell, there are about two to three million disks

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:21.958
having been published -- so 78s, long-playing records and CDs --

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
or at least that's the largest archives of published materials

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
we've been able to sort of point at.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
It costs about 10 dollars a piece to go and take a disk

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
and put it online, if you're doing things in volume.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
But we've found that the rights issues are really quite thorny.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
This is a fairly heavily litigated area,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
so we've found that there are niches in the music world

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
that aren't served terribly well by the classic commercial publishing system.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
And we've been starting to make these available by going

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
and offering shelf space on the Net.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:55.958
In the United States, it doesn't cost you to give something away. Right?

00:13:55.958 --> 00:14:02.958
If you give something to a charity or to the public,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
you get a pat on the back and a tax donation --

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
except on the Net, where you can go broke.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:11.958
If you put up a video of your garage band, and it starts getting heavily accessed,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
you can lose your guitars or your house.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
This doesn't make any sense.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:20.958
So we've offered unlimited storage, unlimited bandwidth, forever, for free,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
to anybody that has something to share that belongs in a library.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And we've been getting a lot of takers. One is the rock 'n' rollers.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
The rock 'n' rollers had a tradition of sharing,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
as long as nobody made any money. You could --

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
concert recordings, it's not the commercial recordings,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
but concert recordings, started by the Grateful Dead.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
And we get about two or three bands a day signing up.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:44.958
They give permission, and we get about 40 or 50 concerts a day.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
We have about 40,000 concerts, everything the Grateful Dead ever did,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:53.958
up on the Net, so that people can see it and listen to this material.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:57.958
So audio is possible to put up, but the rights issues are really pretty thorny.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
We've got a lot of collections now --

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:03.958
a couple hundred thousand items -- and it's growing over time.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
Moving images: if you think of theatrical releases,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
there are not that many of them.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
As best we can tell, there are about 150,000 to 200,000 movies ever

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:16.958
that are really meant for a large-scale theatrical distribution. It's just not that many.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
But half of those were Indian.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
But anyway, it's doable,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
but we've only found about a thousand of these things that --

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
to be out of copyright.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
So we've digitized those and made those available.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
But we've found that there's lots of other types of movies

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
that haven't really seen the light of day -- archival films.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:37.958
We've found, also, a lot of political films, a lot of amateur films,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:42.958
all sorts of things that are basically needing a home, a permanent home.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:46.958
So we've been starting to make these available and it's grown to be very popular.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
We're not quite a YouTube.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
We tended towards longer-term things

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:54.958
and also things that people can reuse and make into new movies,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
which has just been great fun.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Television comes quite a bit larger.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
We started recording 20 channels of television 24 hours a day.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:06.958
It's sort of the biggest TiVo box you've ever seen.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
It's about a petabyte, so far, of worldwide television --

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:14.958
Russian, Chinese, Japanese, Iraqi, Al Jazeera, BBC, CNN, ABC, CBS, NBC --

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
24 hours a day.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
We only put one week up,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:23.958
which is mostly for cost reasons, which is the 9/11,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
sort of from 9/11/2001. For one week, what did the world see?

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:31.958
CNN was saying that Palestinians were dancing in the streets.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
Were they? Let's look at the Palestinian television and find out.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:38.958
How can we have critical thinking without being able to quote

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
and being able to compare what happened in the past?

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:45.958
And television is dreadfully unrecorded and unquotable,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
except by Jon Stewart, who does a fabulous job.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:53.958
So anyway, television is, I would suggest, within our grasp.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:58.958
So 15 dollars per video hour, and also about 100 dollars to 150 dollars per celluloid hour,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:02.958
we're able to go and get materials online very inexpensively

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
and have them up on the Net.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
And we've got, now, a lot of these materials.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
So we've got about 100,000 pieces up there.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:14.958
So books, music, video, software. There's only 50,000 titles of it.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:20.958
Mostly the issues there are legal issues and breaking copy protections.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
But we've worked through some of those,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
but we've still got real problems in Washington.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
Well, we're best known as the World Wide Web.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
We've been archiving the World Wide Web since 1996.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:35.958
We take a snapshot of every website and all of the pages on it, every two months.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:39.958
And actually, it's really been pioneered by Alexa Internet,

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.958
which donates this collection to the Internet Archive.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:49.958
And it's been growing along for the last 11 years, and it's a fantastic resource.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
And we've made a Wayback Machine

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:55.958
that you can then go and see old websites kind of the way they were.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:59.958
If you go and search on something -- this is Google.com,

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
the different versions of it that we have,

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.958
this is what it looks like when it was an alpha release,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
and this is what it looked like at Stanford.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
So anyway, you've got basically an idea of where things came from.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
Mostly, people want to see their old stuff out of this.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:16.958
If there's one thing that we want to learn from the Library of Alexandria version one,

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:20.958
which is probably best known for burning,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
is, don't just have one copy.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:28.958
So we've started to -- we've made another copy of all of this

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:31.958
and we actually put it back in the Library of Alexandria.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:34.958
So this is a picture of the Internet Archive at the Library of Alexandria.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:38.958
And we now have also another copy building up in Amsterdam.

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:42.958
So, we should put it in the San Andreas Fault Line in San Francisco,

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:47.958
flood zone in Amsterdam and in the Middle East. Right, so anyway ...

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
so we're hedging our bets here.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:55.958
If we go and put it in a couple more places, I think we'll be in good shape.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:57.958
There's a political and social question out of this.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:01.958
Is all of this, as we go digital, is it going to be public or private?

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
There's some large companies that have seen this vision,

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:05.958
that are doing large-scale digitization,

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
but they're locking up the public domain.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:10.958
The question is, is that the world that we really want to live in?

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:14.958
What's the role of the public versus the private as things go forward?

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:18.958
How do we go and have a world where we both have libraries

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:23.958

title: Life in the deep oceans
transcript: (Applause) David Gallo: This is Bill Lange. I'm Dave Gallo. And we're going to tell you some stories from the sea here in video. We've got some of the most incredible video of Titanic that's ever been seen, and we're not going to show you any of it. (Laughter)The truth of the matter is that the Titanic — even though it's breaking all sorts of box office records — it's not the most exciting story from the sea. And the problem, I think, is that we take the ocean for granted. When you think about it, the oceans are 75 percent of the planet. Most of the planet is ocean water. The average depth is about two miles. Part of the problem, I think, is we stand at the beach, or we see images like this of the ocean, and you look out at this great big blue expanse, and it's shimmering and it's moving and there's waves and there's surf and there's tides, but you have no idea for what lies in there. And in the oceans, there are the longest mountain ranges on the planet. Most of the animals are in the oceans. Most of the earthquakes and volcanoes are in the sea, at the bottom of the sea. The biodiversity and the biodensity in the ocean is higher, in places, than it is in the rainforests. It's mostly unexplored, and yet there are beautiful sights like this that captivate us and make us become familiar with it.But when you're standing at the beach, I want you to think that you're standing at the edge of a very unfamiliar world. We have to have a very special technology to get into that unfamiliar world. We use the submarine Alvin and we use cameras, and the cameras are something that Bill Lange has developed with the help of Sony. Marcel Proust said, "The true voyage of discovery is not so much in seeking new landscapes as in having new eyes." People that have partnered with us have given us new eyes, not only on what exists — the new landscapes at the bottom of the sea — but also how we think about life on the planet itself.Here's a jelly. It's one of my favorites, because it's got all sorts of working parts. This turns out to be the longest creature in the oceans. It gets up to about 150 feet long. But see all those different working things? I love that kind of stuff. It's got these fishing lures on the bottom. They're going up and down. It's got tentacles dangling, swirling around like that. It's a colonial animal. These are all individual animals banding together to make this one creature. And it's got these jet thrusters up in front that it'll use in a moment, and a little light. If you take all the big fish and schooling fish and all that, put them on one side of the scale, put all the jelly-type of animals on the other side, those guys win hands down.Most of the biomass in the ocean is made out of creatures like this. Here's the X-wing death jelly. (Laughter) The bioluminescence — they use the lights for attracting mates and attracting prey and communicating. We couldn't begin to show you our archival stuff from the jellies. They come in all different sizes and shapes.Bill Lange: We tend to forget about the fact that the ocean is miles deep on average, and that we're real familiar with the animals that are in the first 200 or 300 feet, but we're not familiar with what exists from there all the way down to the bottom. And these are the types of animals that live in that three-dimensional space, that micro-gravity environment that we really haven't explored. You hear about giant squid and things like that, but some of these animals get up to be approximately 140, 160 feet long. They're very little understood.DG: This is one of them, another one of our favorites, because it's a little octopod. You can actually see through his head. And here he is, flapping with his ears and very gracefully going up. We see those at all depths and even at the greatest depths. They go from a couple of inches to a couple of feet. They come right up to the submarine — they'll put their eyes right up to the window and peek inside the sub.This is really a world within a world, and we're going to show you two. In this case, we're passing down through the mid-ocean and we see creatures like this. This is kind of like an undersea rooster. This guy, that looks incredibly formal, in a way. And then one of my favorites. What a face! This is basically scientific data that you're looking at. It's footage that we've collected for scientific purposes. And that's one of the things that Bill's been doing, is providing scientists with this first view of animals like this, in the world where they belong. They don't catch them in a net. They're actually looking at them down in that world. We're going to take a joystick, sit in front of our computer, on the Earth, and press the joystick forward, and fly around the planet.We're going to look at the mid-ocean ridge, a 40,000-mile long mountain range. The average depth at the top of it is about a mile and a half. And we're over the Atlantic — that's the ridge right there — but we're going to go across the Caribbean, Central America, and end up against the Pacific, nine degrees north. We make maps of these mountain ranges with sound, with sonar, and this is one of those mountain ranges. We're coming around a cliff here on the right. The height of these mountains on either side of this valley is greater than the Alps in most cases. And there's tens of thousands of those mountains out there that haven't been mapped yet.This is a volcanic ridge. We're getting down further and further in scale. And eventually, we can come up with something like this.This is an icon of our robot, Jason, it's called. And you can sit in a room like this, with a joystick and a headset, and drive a robot like that around the bottom of the ocean in real time. One of the things we're trying to do at Woods Hole with our partners is to bring this virtual world — this world, this unexplored region — back to the laboratory. Because we see it in bits and pieces right now. We see it either as sound, or we see it as video, or we see it as photographs, or we see it as chemical sensors, but we never have yet put it all together into one interesting picture.Here's where Bill's cameras really do shine. This is what's called a hydrothermal vent. And what you're seeing here is a cloud of densely packed, hydrogen-sulfide-rich water coming out of a volcanic axis on the sea floor. Gets up to 600, 700 degrees F, somewhere in that range. So that's all water under the sea — a mile and a half, two miles, three miles down. And we knew it was volcanic back in the '60s, '70s. And then we had some hint that these things existed all along the axis of it, because if you've got volcanism, water's going to get down from the sea into cracks in the sea floor, come in contact with magma, and come shooting out hot. We weren't really aware that it would be so rich with sulfides, hydrogen sulfides. We didn't have any idea about these things, which we call chimneys.This is one of these hydrothermal vents. Six hundred degree F water coming out of the Earth. On either side of us are mountain ranges that are higher than the Alps, so the setting here is very dramatic.BL: The white material is a type of bacteria that thrives at 180 degrees C.DG: I think that's one of the greatest stories right now that we're seeing from the bottom of the sea, is that the first thing we see coming out of the sea floor after a volcanic eruption is bacteria. And we started to wonder for a long time, how did it all get down there? What we find out now is that it's probably coming from inside the Earth. Not only is it coming out of the Earth — so, biogenesis made from volcanic activity — but that bacteria supports these colonies of life. The pressure here is 4,000 pounds per square inch. A mile and a half from the surface to two miles to three miles — no sun has ever gotten down here. All the energy to support these life forms is coming from inside the Earth — so, chemosynthesis. And you can see how dense the population is. These are called tube worms.BL: These worms have no digestive system. They have no mouth. But they have two types of gill structures. One for extracting oxygen out of the deep-sea water, another one which houses this chemosynthetic bacteria, which takes the hydrothermal fluid — that hot water that you saw coming out of the bottom — and converts that into simple sugars that the tube worm can digest.DG: You can see, here's a crab that lives down there. He's managed to grab a tip of these worms. Now, they normally retract as soon as a crab touches them. Oh! Good going. So, as soon as a crab touches them, they retract down into their shells, just like your fingernails. There's a whole story being played out here that we're just now beginning to have some idea of because of this new camera technology.BL: These worms live in a real temperature extreme. Their foot is at about 200 degrees C and their head is out at three degrees C, so it's like having your hand in boiling water and your foot in freezing water. That's how they like to live. (Laughter)DG: This is a female of this kind of worm. And here's a male. You watch. It doesn't take long before two guys here — this one and one that will show up over here — start to fight. Everything you see is played out in the pitch black of the deep sea. There are never any lights there, except the lights that we bring. Here they go. On one of the last dive series, we counted 200 species in these areas — 198 were new, new species.BL: One of the big problems is that for the biologists working at these sites, it's rather difficult to collect these animals. And they disintegrate on the way up, so the imagery is critical for the science.DG: Two octopods at about two miles depth. This pressure thing really amazes me — that these animals can exist there at a depth with pressure enough to crush the Titanic like an empty Pepsi can. What we saw up till now was from the Pacific. This is from the Atlantic. Even greater depth. You can see this shrimp is harassing this poor little guy here, and he'll bat it away with his claw. Whack! (Laughter)And the same thing's going on over here. What they're getting at is that — on the back of this crab — the foodstuff here is this very strange bacteria that lives on the backs of all these animals. And what these shrimp are trying to do is actually harvest the bacteria from the backs of these animals. And the crabs don't like it at all. These long filaments that you see on the back of the crab are actually created by the product of that bacteria. So, the bacteria grows hair on the crab. On the back, you see this again. The red dot is the laser light of the submarine Alvin to give us an idea about how far away we are from the vents. Those are all shrimp. You see the hot water over here, here and here, coming out. They're clinging to a rock face and actually scraping bacteria off that rock face. Here's a tiny, little vent that's come out of the side of that pillar. Those pillars get up to several stories. So here, you've got this valley with this incredible alien landscape of pillars and hot springs and volcanic eruptions and earthquakes, inhabited by these very strange animals that live only on chemical energy coming out of the ground. They don't need the sun at all.BL: You see this white V-shaped mark on the back of the shrimp? It's actually a light-sensing organ. It's how they find the hydrothermal vents. The vents are emitting a black body radiation — an IR signature — and so they're able to find these vents at considerable distances.DG: All this stuff is happening along that 40,000-mile long mountain range that we're calling the ribbon of life, because just even today, as we speak, there's life being generated there from volcanic activity. This is the first time we've ever tried this any place. We're going to try to show you high definition from the Pacific. We're moving up one of these pillars. This one's several stories tall. In it, you'll see that it's a habitat for a lot of different animals. There's a funny kind of hot plate here, with vent water coming out of it. So all of these are individual homes for worms.Now here's a closer view of that community. Here's crabs here, worms here. There are smaller animals crawling around. Here's pagoda structures. I think this is the neatest-looking thing. I just can't get over this — that you've got these little chimneys sitting here smoking away. This stuff is toxic as hell, by the way. You could never get a permit to dump this in the ocean, and it's coming out all from it. (Laughter) It's unbelievable. It's basically sulfuric acid, and it's being just dumped out, at incredible rates. And animals are thriving — and we probably came from here. That's probably where we evolved from.BL: This bacteria that we've been talking about turns out to be the most simplest form of life found. There are a number of groups that are proposing that life evolved at these vent sites. Although the vent sites are short-lived — an individual site may last only 10 years or so — as an ecosystem they've been stable for millions — well, billions — of years.DG: It works too well. You see there're some fish inside here as well. There's a fish sitting here. Here's a crab with his claw right at the end of that tube worm, waiting for that worm to stick his head out. (Laughter)BL: The biologists right now cannot explain why these animals are so active. The worms are growing inches per week!DG: I already said that this site, from a human perspective, is toxic as hell. Not only that, but on top — the lifeblood — that plumbing system turns off every year or so. Their plumbing system turns off, so the sites have to move. And then there's earthquakes, and then volcanic eruptions, on the order of one every five years, that completely wipes the area out. Despite that, these animals grow back in about a year's time. You're talking about biodensities and biodiversity, again, higher than the rainforest that just springs back to life. Is it sensitive? Yes. Is it fragile? No, it's not really very fragile.I'll end up with saying one thing. There's a story in the sea, in the waters of the sea, in the sediments and the rocks of the sea floor. It's an incredible story. What we see when we look back in time, in those sediments and rocks, is a record of Earth history. Everything on this planet — everything — works by cycles and rhythms. The continents move apart. They come back together. Oceans come and go. Mountains come and go. Glaciers come and go. El Nino comes and goes. It's not a disaster, it's rhythmic. What we're learning now, it's almost like a symphony. It's just like music — it really is just like music. And what we're learning now is that you can't listen to a five-billion-year long symphony, get to today and say, "Stop! We want tomorrow's note to be the same as it was today." It's absurd. It's just absurd. So, what we've got to learn now is to find out where this planet's going at all these different scales and work with it. Learn to manage it. The concept of preservation is futile. Conservation's tougher, but we can probably get there. Thank you very much. Thank you. (Applause)
